As people who own and use guns respectfully, we feel an urgency to speak up for a simple, sensible approach.Hunters and hunting are also declining. In 1955, 10 percent of Americans hunted. Today, itâ€™s less than 5 percent. But the positive image of the hunter as a skilled and conscientious â€œsportsmanâ€ is being abused in defense of an out-of-control gun culture. Most hunters own guns principally to hunt game. We use them safely and respectfully: If someone is injured during their use, it will most likely be a friend or family member, since that is who we hunt with. We donâ€™t buy a lot of guns. We usually have a few favorites, often passed down to us by fathers or grandfathers. The gun industry figured that out decades ago, and switched to creating guns for a different market.Thatâ€™s not to say that all hunters are like-minded on the issue of regulating firearms. As our numbers have dwindled, many have found a comforting alliance with Second Amendment radicalism. But we believe this is not representative of most hunters, and certainly not the tradition of the hunter-sportsman. We do not need AR-15s or any assault-style weapon to hunt game. Thatâ€™s not to say some people wonâ€™t use them to hunt. But they are simply not necessary, and are actually not preferable for legitimate, fair-chase hunting.We believe that simple, responsible reforms in firearm policy are an urgent necessity. Hunting and hunters should not be seen, or used, as a shield against constructive bipartisan solutions. We see the need and opportunity to frame compromise between the Second Amendmentâ€™s right to keep and bear arms and the Fifth Amendmentâ€™s right to life and liberty.Hereâ€™s where we would begin:1. An age minimum of 21 years to purchase any gun;2. Anyone on the Terrorist Screening Centerâ€™s â€œno-fly listâ€ may not purchase or possess firearms;3. Anyone on Social Security disability due to mental illness may not purchase or possess firearms;4. Prohibit new sales of semiautomatic assault or tactical-style weapons;5. Prohibit new sales of semiautomatic shotguns or rifles (except .22-caliber rim fire) that can hold more than 10 rounds;6. Prohibit any accessory designed or mechanical modification intended a) to increase the rate at which any firearm may be discharged; or b) to increase the magazine capacity of a semiautomatic rifle beyond 10 rounds (except .22-caliber rim fire);7. Mandatory and universal background checks for all firearm sales;8. Prohibit sales of firearms except through registered/licensed dealers (no direct private sales);9. Enact gun violence restraining order authorities allowing courts to temporarily prohibit a person from purchasing or possessing firearms when a family member, community welfare expert or law enforcement officer presents evidence of a threat; and10. Repeal the â€œDickey banâ€ on scientific research in the area of gun violence and implement the Institute of Medicineâ€™s 2013 gun violence research agenda. These suggestions are simple to implement and enforce. They do limit the rights of honest and law-abiding citizens, but they are responsible limitations that do not infringe the ability of Americans to hunt, shoot,Â or protect themselves and their families. And in comparison to the 17 people at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School who have been stripped of all of their rights, and of life and liberty, it is a small price to pay. There are simple, responsible solutions. No one should use hunters and hunting as an excuse to avoid pursuing them.Daniel M. Ashe, former U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service directorTed Williams, environmental journalist*Paula Del Giudice,Â outdoor writer and hunter*Mike Furtman, outdoor writer and photographer, hunter and former gun dealer*Jim Low, former president of the Outdoor Writers Association of America and 13-time recipient of the Izaak Walton Leagueâ€™s Outdoor Ethics Communication Award*Dr. Leonard Lee Rue III, wildlife photographer*Brian Rutledge, conservation leader and naturalistScott Stouder, outdoor writer, conservationist and lifelong hunter*Dr. Kris Thoemke, outdoor writer, conservationist and hunter*Joel Vance, current member and former president of the Outdoor Writers Association of America*George Harrison, retired nature journalist*Rich Patterson, former president of the Outdoor Writers Association of America**Member of the Circle of Chiefs, the highest conservation honor of the Outdoor Writers Association of America

DALLAS â€• John Lott, the National Rifle Associationâ€™s favorite academic and gun researcher, had a question for the mostly older, white, male crowd seated in front of him.How many of them had heard someone say that federal gun research has been stymied for years because of Congress? Or that the U.S. has aÂ uniquely high rate of gun homicide compared to other nations? Or thatÂ guns make suicide easier?All those claims were lies, he said, told by gun control advocates and repeated by an unquestioning media intent on pushing an anti-gun agenda.Over the weekend the NRA held its 147th annual convention, and Lott, whose highly discreditedÂ book More Guns, Less Crime, is considered the bible of the gun lobby, addressed a packed room inside the Kay Hutchison Convention Center here in downtown Dallas. For three days, gun rights enthusiasts gathered to peruse the newest firearms and gear, attend educational seminars such as â€œRefuse to be a victim: Crime prevention strategies,â€ and â€œ14 factors impacting your shooting performance under duress,â€ and to simply have fun.Many were also there to send a pointed political message: NRA, we support you.The NRA is now on the defense as it faces off against a country that is mostly fed up with current gun control laws that did not prevent horrific mass shootings like those that took place in Las Vegas,Â Sutherland Springs, Texas,Â and most recently in Parkland, Florida.Since February, the U.S. has witnessed nationwide protests, student walkouts and countless state legislative wins. This coming November, advocates promise to vote out politicians who take money from the NRA, which opposes virtually every state and federal effort to tighten existing gun laws or pass any new gun safety measures.At the convention, many attendees disputed the idea that gun control is gaining momentum. Instead, they said it was a false narrative created by the media. Fake news, in other words. Many participants told HuffPost that journalists ignore positive stories about guns, such as home invasions thwarted by gun owners. They said the media spends a disproportionate amount of time covering gun violence.â€œItâ€™s what the press chooses to cover,â€ said Brian Lilly, 49, who attended the convention for the first time this year, alongside his father and his 18-year-old son, Benjamin. â€œThey are censoring what the true pulse of the citizenry thinks.â€When his son, a high school senior, was asked what he thought about his fellow students who were advocating for gun control, he exhaled sharply.â€œI think they want to get out of class,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s whatâ€™s on the news. They canâ€™t back up their claims. They donâ€™t know what theyâ€™re talking about.â€ The biggest misperception about guns is that â€œtheyâ€™re always used for bad things and theyâ€™re not used for good,â€ he said.Dante Martin, 52, agreed. He stood at the Beretta booth, testing out a semi-automatic handgun he was looking to potentially acquire for his wife. It was his first convention despite being an NRA member for a decade. This year, he brought his 15-year-old son as a reward for getting good grades.â€œGuns donâ€™t kill people â€• people kill people,â€ Martin said. â€œEveryone has sympathy for people who were killed in these horrific events, but how many people are killed by drunk drivers? Whereâ€™s the outrage there?â€He, like others interviewed, said that if guns were removed, perpetrators would just use vehicles to commit mass murder. â€œWithout your second amendment rights, all the other [amendments] are just suggestions,â€ he added.Inside the sprawling exhibit hall, giant photos of NRA leaders bore down on members as they pointed and pulled the triggers of unloaded firearms, the sound of metallic clicks filling the air. There was a tone of jubilance and celebration.A poster with a silhouette of a woman carrying a grocery bag in the dark asked ominously if she was â€œtrained for whatâ€™s around the next corner.â€ Dozens of people lined up to try a virtual reality simulator to test their firearm skills in a self-defense scenario. As people examined firearms on the floor, it was common to see them pointed directly at passersby.Â Â Outside the convention, cars decked out with enlarged photos of victims of gun violence circled the center, weaving between an endless stream of convention-goers as they crossed the street. Protesters gathered on Friday and Saturday to rally against the gun group but were greatly outnumbered by the more than 87,000 people who attended the NRA event,Â which set a new record.Â The site of the convention was notable for its proximity to two historic acts of violence. It is blocks from where Lee Harvey Oswald assassinated President John F. Kennedy, using a mail-order rifle he bought from an ad in the NRAâ€™s American Rifleman magazine, and the location of a police ambush in 2016 in which five police officers were killed.Manuel Oliver, whose son Joaquin was fatally shot at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland,Â implored President Donald Trump to listen to survivors as he painted a mural on Saturday, in front of hundreds of protesters. Â â€œIâ€™m impressed with the support that the NRA got from our president yesterday,â€ Oliver said, his voice strained. â€œI havenâ€™t heard from President Trump the name of my son, not even once.â€Speaking in front of the NRA on Friday, Trump appeared comfortable and happy, buoyed by the enthusiasm of the crowd who laughed uproariously at his jokes. In a typically meandering speech, he made fun of John Kerry for breaking his leg and thanked rap artist Kanye West for boosting his poll numbers among black Americans. He also mimicked the mass shooting at the Bataclan theater in Paris using finger guns. No one laughed at that.He urged NRA members to get out and vote in November.â€œWe cannot get complacent,â€ he said. â€œWe have to win the midterms.â€ Attendees said they were not fazed by Trumpâ€™s inconsistencies on gun rights. After the Parkland shooting, he suggested that firearms should be immediately confiscated from people deemed dangerous, raising alarms among gun rights proponents. â€œI think heâ€™s in our corner,â€ said Mr. Nichols, a retired military member from San Antonio who only gave his last name. â€œI tend to look at his actions, not always what he says.â€â€œThe only thing I wish he would do is stop tweeting,â€ said a 52-year-old Texas man who only wanted to be identified by his first name, Donald. â€œShut up and get offline.â€Donald said he was a â€œlifetime memberâ€ of the NRA, a level of membership which costs $1,500 and does not ever need to be renewed. He was at the convention with his wife and son. All three work in their family-owned barbecue restaurant, which has been broken into five times. They keep a gun on site for protection. His son become a lifetime NRA member earlier that day. The NRA are â€œon the front lines, fighting for our rights,â€ Donald said. â€œIndividually, I donâ€™t feel like I have any power, but as part of a group I do.â€

Tens of thousands ofÂ National Rifle AssociationÂ members descended on Dallas this week for the gun advocacy groupâ€™s 147th annual meeting â€• once again with an assist from President Donald Trump.Â Ahead of the event, which ran from Thursday to Sunday, the NRA said that 80,000 members would be attending and billed it as the largestÂ in the organizationâ€™s history. But outside the convention center, another crowd assembled to protest the NRAâ€™s efforts to stifle gun control laws.In the year since the last meeting, the U.S. had itsÂ deadliest mass shooting in recent history when a gunman killed 58 people and wounded hundreds in Las Vegas. And it saw a powerful uprising of young gun control advocates after a shooter gunned down 17 students and faculty members at a high school in Parkland, Florida.Â The meeting was also a chance for commerce,Â with vendors taking orders for firearms, and it gave Trump a chance to address the crowd for the fourth year in a row. This year, people lined up hours early to get into the arena where he regurgitated many of his favorite pro-gun talking points.Take a look at photos from the annual event below:Clarification:Â Language in this story has been amended to clarify that vendors take orders for gun purchases at the NRA convention;Â those orders are finalized via customersâ€™ local gun dealers.

DALLAS â€• The father of a student slain in the Parkland, Florida, school shooting challenged President Donald Trump to visit his home and see his dead sonâ€™s bedroom.Â â€œI havenâ€™t heard from President Trump the name of my son, not even once,â€ said Manuel Oliver, speaking during aÂ student-led rallyÂ outside City Hall in Dallas, Texas, on Saturday morning. Hundreds of activists and students gathered to protest the National Rifle Association, which is holding its annual meeting nearby.Â â€œIt takes one second â€• â€˜Joaquin Oliverâ€™ â€• and you are not able to mention that name,â€ he said, addressing Trump directly. â€œIt is important, your support, because you could make things happen along with us. Let me rephrase that: You could make it happen faster, because we are going to make it happen.â€Oliverâ€™s son, Joaquin, was fatally shot alongside 16 other people during the Feb. 14 shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida. The survivors of that tragedy, one of the deadliest school shootings in modern U.S. history, have now emerged as leaders of a freshly invigorated national gun control movement, which has set its sights on the NRA.Oliver live-painted a protest mural in honor of his son, between speeches by gun control activists and students. At the end, he walked onto the stage with a hammer.Â â€œLetâ€™s feel how it feels to be in a school hall and listen to something like this,â€ he said, before loudly smashing holes in 17 stick figures illustrated on the giant canvas. He then stuck a sunflower through each one.Â Â Just a block away from the protest, thousands of members of the countryâ€™s most powerful gun group strolled inside the Kay Hutchison Convention Center, shopping the NRA store, taking seminars and perusing â€œ15 acres of guns and gearâ€ inside the exhibit hall.The annual convention, now in its 147th year, comes at a particularly tense moment for the NRA.Â This yearâ€™s theme is â€œa show of strength,â€ and the NRA appears to be in a defensive posture. In a speech on Friday, the groupâ€™s chief lobbyist, Chris Cox, urged members not to be ashamed.Â â€œWhat they really want is for you to be afraid to publicly associate with this organization,â€ he said. â€œThey donâ€™t want you wearing an NRA hat or putting an NRA sticker on your car or truck.â€Â He encouraged attendees to stand tall and â€œstand proud.â€Trump and Vice President Mike Pence spoke to members on Friday inside a packed area. Both leaders advocated arming teachers and increasing security in schools to protect children.Â Outside City Hall, Rosie Wallace, 29, and Kenna Edwards, 25, said they came to the protest because they want to see fewer school shootings and more common-sense gun reform.They both admired Oliverâ€™s mural.Â â€œItâ€™s really moving that someone would be so expressive about losing their child and willing to sacrifice their time to make a change for something they believe in,â€ said Wallace, an environmental scientist for the Environmental Protection Agency.Â Edwards, who works at a software company, said she was disappointed in Dallas for allowing the NRA convention to be held there.â€œItâ€™s on-brand for Dallas, but as a resident, I donâ€™t like it,â€ she said.Â Julia Heilrayne, an Austin, Texas, high school student, attended the protest with a red target printed on her forehead. She spoke with HuffPost at a smaller protest in front of City Hall the night before. Since the Parkland shooting, she said, students at her school are skittish if they hear a loud noise, like a chip bag popping in the cafeteria.Â Â â€œYou can drop a textbook in the hallway, and everyone freezes,â€ she said.Â Heilrayne said she got involved in the gun control movement after a friend of hers â€• a third-grader â€• was shot and killed in 2017.Â â€œI had to fight for her,â€ she said. â€œI had to be her voice, because she doesnâ€™t have one any more.â€After the gun control protest wrapped up, a group of counterprotesters gathered nearby openly carrying firearms.Lawrence Solem, 40, a machinery mechanic from Lewisville, Texas, said he wanted to show his support for the right to carry.â€œEvil can and always will exist in the world,â€ he said. â€œEvil doesnâ€™t care about time or location. Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s safest to carry at all times.â€

Fox News anchor Shepard Smith sharply criticized PresidentÂ Donald TrumpÂ on Friday for headlining the National Rifle Association convention mere months after he vowed to take action on gun control in the wake of the deadlyÂ school shootingÂ in Parkland, Florida, in which 17 people died.Just after that shooting, Trump had taunted lawmakers for failing to act on gun control, claiming in a televised roundtable discussion that they were â€œafraidâ€ of the NRA. He talked about raising the age for legal purchases of assault-style AR-15s from 18 to 21, banning bump stocks boosting the firepower of AR-15s, and tightening up background checks on gun buyers.Instead, Smith observed, Trump went to Dallas to headline for the powerful national gun lobbying groupâ€™s meeting, where heÂ â€œfalsely stated that Democrats want all guns outlawed.â€Â  Â While Trump and the NRA are now pushing to arm teachers in schools, the NRAâ€™s Leadership Forum itself was, ironically, aÂ â€œgun-free zoneâ€Â to protect Trump and Vice President Mike Pence.Smith also noted Trump and attorney Rudy Giulianiâ€™s reversals on the Stormy Daniels payment saga. Giuliani revealed Wednesday that Trump hadÂ reimbursed his attorney Michael Cohenâ€™s $130,000 payment to Daniels, the adult film star who alleges she had an affair with Trump.Trump appeared to support Giuliani in a tweet on Thursday, but then insisted Friday that his new attorney needed to get his facts straight.â€œMaybe theyâ€™re just trying to confuse everybody,â€ said Smith. â€œWhat team Trump said last month, then changed last week, then re-imagined again on Tuesday was revised and extended againâ€ on Friday, he said. â€œAnd space under the bus is now at a premium.Â Rudy Giuliani found himself wedged there today.â€Â Giuliani issued a statement Friday nearly as tortured as the Trump teamâ€™s Daniels story: â€œMy references to timing were not describing my understanding of the presidentâ€™s knowledge but instead my understanding of these matters.â€Â â€œNow let this one sink in just in case this version lasts more than a few hours,â€ Smith quipped.Watch Smithâ€™s remarks in the video at the top of this story.

In his address at the National Rifle Associationâ€™s annual Dallas convention Friday, PresidentÂ Donald TrumpÂ swerved toÂ thank Kanye West for supposedly doubling his African-American poll numbers before getting right to the point: â€œLetâ€™s talk about guns, shall we?â€Â The president then proceeded to dole out some questionable information on guns, gun control and people who carry guns.Here are the highlights.Â The statistic Trump cited comes from the Crime Prevention Research Center, which claims that,Â in a span of more than six decades, 98 percent of mass shootings occurred in â€œgun-free zones.â€Â Take it with a big grain of salt: The study was authored by John Lott, a gun rights advocate and author of a recentÂ controversialÂ New York Times op-ed on background checks. The meaning of the statistic heavily depends on how both â€œmass shootingâ€Â and â€œgun-free zoneâ€ are defined.An official definition of â€œmass shootingâ€ doesnâ€™t exist, and thereâ€™s a lot of debate over which incidents count and which donâ€™t. The FBI stipulates thatÂ three or more people must be killed for the term to apply, but Lott defined it as four or more deaths in public. By doing so, he discounted private residences where domestic violence-related shootings have occurred. He also did not count shootings that were â€œpart of another crime,â€ such as a robbery.Â Thereâ€™s also no official way to define â€œgun-free zone,â€ which may apply to places where civilians canâ€™t carry firearms but officials can. The way Lott chose to define it in his research is questionable; for example, he considered military sites like Fort Hood to be â€˜gun-free zones,â€™ even though guns are clearly present there.That gun-carrying civilians lead to crime prevention is an old NRA talking point: A good guy with a gun stops a bad guy with a gun. ExpertsÂ strongly disputeÂ this idea. The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine concluded in 2005 that â€œno link between right-to-carry laws and changes in crime is apparent in the raw data.â€PolitiFact deemed the statistic Trump cited Friday only â€œhalf-true.â€â€œThere is no sign more inviting to a mass killer than a sign that declares that this school is a gun-free zone,â€ Trump said at the convention, repeating his proposal to arm some teachersÂ and school security guards.HuffPostâ€™s Rebecca Klein spoke to teachers and law enforcement officials about Trumpâ€™s idea and found many of them were against it, including the national teachers unions. Many worried that such a policy would do more harm than good and lead to a lot of students being injured by accident at school.Â â€œAnyone who hasnâ€™t received the extensive training provided to law enforcement officers will likely be mentally unprepared to take a life, especially the life of a student assailant,â€ Mo Canady, the executive director of the National Association for School Resource Officers, said in a statement.Â â€œWe all know whatâ€™s going on in Chicago, but Chicago has the toughest gun laws in our country,â€ Trump said Friday.Trump and others in the pro-gun crowd have long held up crime rates in Chicago as evidence that gun control doesnâ€™t work. Although both Illinois and its largest city do have strong gun laws,Â Chicago is a short drive from both Wisconsin and Indiana, where laws are significantly weaker. Studies have found that most of the guns used in crimes in Chicago come from out of state, with many coming from much farther away.Beyond that, Trumpâ€™s comments ignore the fact that homicides and shootings in Chicago have actually been on the decline for more than a year. In 2017, Chicago had the ninth-highest homicide rate of any U.S. city.â€œParis, France, has the toughest gun laws in the world,â€ said Trump, going on to explain how a small group of terrorists armed with AK-47s â€œbrutally killedâ€ more than 130 people in the French capital in 2015.â€œIf one employee or just one patron had a gun â€¦ the terrorists would have fled or been shot, and it wouldâ€™ve been a whole different story.â€This is another of Trumpâ€™s favorite talking points, which heâ€™s been using since the November 2015 Bataclan massacre.Putting aside for a second the absolute chaos that might have ensued if an arena full of armed concertgoers had decided to open fire on their assailants in the pitch dark, Trump is also leaving out some broader context. With its strong gun laws, the overall firearm death rate in France is about one-quarter of what it is in the U.S. Although violent crime is not unheard of in Paris, the city experiences just a fraction of the homicides that an American city of a comparable population does. Gun homicides also appear to be primarily an issue among rival criminal gangs.â€œI recently read a story that in London, which has unbelievably tough gun laws, a once very prestigious hospital right in the middle, is like a war zone for horrible stabbing wounds,â€ said Trump. â€œYes, thatâ€™s right, they donâ€™t have guns, they have knives, and instead thereâ€™s blood all over the floors of this hospital.â€Weâ€™re not really sure what Trumpâ€™s point is here. If heâ€™s noting that all violence is not gun violence, then sure. But the fact that Londoners are making it to hospitals to receive care is significant. Knives tend to be less lethal than guns, and itâ€™s far easier to injure or kill larger numbers of people, often indiscriminately or unintentionally, by shooting than it is by stabbing.A recent study in the U.S. found that more gunshot victims are dying before reaching the emergency room than they were a decade ago, even as trauma care has improved. One theory for this trend is an increasing â€œintensityâ€ of violence, suggesting people may be getting shot more times, at closer range, with higher-caliber rounds, or simply while farther from the nearest hospital.Thereâ€™s no saying how much worse the problem would be in London if it were as easy to get a gun there as it is in the U.S.

Harley-Davidson Inc. announced it is shifting production of some of its motorcycles to Europe because of President Donald Trumpâ€™s escalating trade war, which critics warn could hamstring the humming U.S. economy and cost jobs.Trump hosted executives from the Milwaukee-based company and the union officials representing its workers last year at the White House. The president hailed the company as a model of American manufacturing, an industry he promised to restore. He further praised the executives â€œfor building things in Americaâ€ and predicted the company would expand its operations during his administration.Things arenâ€™t looking so great for the iconic motorcycle producer this year, however. The company said in a regulatory filing on Monday that retaliatory tariffs imposed on American exports by the European Union rose between 6 percent and 31 percent this year, resulting in a jump in $2,200 per average motorcycle exported to the EU.But rather than hike prices in the U.S., the company said it would absorb the cost in the short term â€•Â projected to be some $30 million to $45 million through this yearâ€• and shift some production to international factories in coming months.â€œIncreasing international production to alleviate the EU tariff burden is not the companyâ€™s preference, but represents the only sustainable option to make its motorcycles accessible to customers in the EU and maintain a viable business in Europe. Europe is a critical market for Harley-Davidson,â€ the company said in a statement.The move follows a round of layoffs at the companyâ€™s manufacturing plants in Milwaukee and Kansas City, Missouri, last year, costing 180 manufacturing jobs.Trump tweetedÂ MondayÂ that he was â€œsurprisedâ€ by Harley-Davidsonâ€™s decision to move some production overseas, urging the company to be â€œpatient.â€Trump on Friday furtherÂ threatened to escalate a trade warÂ with Europe by imposing a 20 percent tariff on all U.S. imports of EU-assembled cars.Republican leaders in Congress have so far resisted challenging Trump on trade, worrying that an intraparty clash could harm the party in Novemberâ€™s midterm elections. But there are signs that some members of the presidentâ€™s party â€• which historically has favored free trade â€• may finally be reaching a breaking point.Â Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.), for example, warned over the weekend that heâ€™s prepared to oppose Trumpâ€™s judicial nominees unless the Senate votes on legislation curtailing the presidentâ€™s power to unilaterally impose tariffs on other countries.â€œI think myself and a number of senators, at least a few of us, will stand up and say, â€˜Letâ€™s not move any more judges until we get a vote, for example, on tariffs,â€™â€ Flake, who is retiring this year, said on ABCâ€™s â€œThis Week.â€This story has been updated with Trumpâ€™s Monday tweet.

CNN White House correspondent Jim Acosta was heckled at President Donald Trumpâ€™s rally in South Carolina on Monday as members of the crowd chanted â€œGo home!â€ and â€œCNN sucks!â€Acosta was reportedly waiting in the press area at the rally in West Columbia, where the president was about to campaign for the stateâ€™s Republican Gov. Henry McMaster. But before Trump arrived, attendees holding signs reading â€œCNN fake newsâ€ began chanting for the reporter to leave the venue. At one point, a woman pointed at the journalist, repeating â€œTake him outâ€ and urging her fellow rally-goers to heckle him.Acosta attempted to shake the womanâ€™s hand, telling her he had a right to cover the event. He then said that he respected the United States as the woman waved her arms at him.â€œNo! You do not respect it,â€ the woman yelled.Acosta later addressed the event on CNN.â€œWhile we have had people come up to us and be nice, I did have an elderly woman come up to me just a short while ago,â€ he told CNNâ€™s Wolf Blitzer. â€œShe came up to me and said that we at CNN should get the â€˜fâ€™ out of this auditorium. She then turned to the crowd and whipped them up into a frenzy.â€He continued: â€œWe are here to do our jobs and report the news and report on this rally, and weâ€™re not going anywhere.â€Later in the evening, Trump began his speech on a familiar note, attacking the press and calling media outlets gathered at the rally â€œfake news,â€ a taunt that drew raucous boos and jeers.Â â€œThe enemy, the enemy of the people I call â€™em,â€Â the president said of the media.Despite his continued attacks on CNN, he appeared to set his sights on a new target following an exchange of barbs with late-night host Jimmy Fallon this week. â€œNBC is worse actually than CNN,â€ Trump quipped.Acosta has often earned the ire of the president and other White House officials, including press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders, over the past year. Trumpâ€™s 2020 campaign manager, Brad Parscale, recently called for the journalistâ€™s press credentials to be suspended after Acosta shouted questions at Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un during a summit in Singapore earlier this month.â€œDear Brad.. dictatorships take away press credentials,â€ AcostaÂ fired backÂ on Twitter. â€œNot democracies.â€

LeBron James Jr. will soon join his superstar father above the rim â€• but he isnâ€™t there just yet.The 13-year-old tried a dunk for the first time in a game over the weekend in the â€œBallinâ€™ on the Beachâ€ AAU tournament in Miami.He caught his dad by surprise. â€œMan what!?!?!â€ the future Hall of Famer wrote of the teen trying to complete one of basketballâ€™s rites of passage.â€œBronnyâ€ dribbled most of the floor and sprung up for a one-handed jam just like dad â€• but without stuffing the ball through the hoop. Heâ€™s bound to improve with a bit more hops and bigger hands.Still, not a bad first try.Watch his dad react below.Bronny, as he is often called, has shown himself to be a chip off the old block for years. And he caught the attention of college coaches long ago.Pretty soon heâ€™ll have a repertoire of dunks to show off, too.

An Oregon National Guardsman is facing disciplinary action after suggesting that undocumented immigrants are â€œlucky we arenâ€™t executing them.â€Private First Class Gerod Martin wrote the offensive comment Wednesday on a Facebook page to raise funds for the Texas-based Refugee and Immigrant Center for Education and Legal Services.â€œWaste of money,â€ Martin, 21, wrote in a comment that has since been deleted. â€œTheyâ€™re lucky we arenâ€™t executing them.â€Martinâ€™s Facebook account appears to have been deleted as well, or has been set to private. Screenshots of Martinâ€™s page show him wearing his Oregon National Guard uniform in his profile picture. â€œJust a young buck serving his country,â€Â he wrote on the page.Martinâ€™s comments violated the uniform code of military justice,Â Maj. Stephen Bomar of the Oregon National Guard told ABC affiliate KATU. He said the organization will hold Martin accountable for his actions but hasnâ€™t decided on a punishment yet.â€œThis was a clear violation in uniform to say anything like that, or anything political because we enforce the policies of our politicians,â€ Bomar said. â€œThat was just a horrific comment.â€The Oregon National Guard has strict rules on social media conduct, Bomar added.â€œOne of our policies is to conduct yourself as though youâ€™re a servicemember 24/7,â€ he said. â€œEven if you are working a civilian job, you are still part of our team and need to remember to have those values wherever you go.â€HuffPost was unable to reach Martin for comment.TheÂ viral Facebook fundraiser to help immigrant families, which a couple in California created last week in response to the Trump administrationâ€™s highly controversial family separation policy, has raised over $20 million.Backlash over the policy prompted President Donald Trump to sign an executive order to end family separation at the border by detaining children and parents together.

Netflix adds a movie youâ€™ve likely already seen this week. And if you havenâ€™t seen it, now is your chance to finally catch up with the American zeitgeist.â€œStar Wars: The Last Jediâ€ joins on June 26. The movie earned well over $1 billion at the box office and only debuted in theaters last December. Itâ€™s fairly rare that Netflix adds such a recently popular movie, so this is a particularly noteworthy addition.If youâ€™ve already seen the movie or simply arenâ€™t a fan of â€œStar Wars,â€ Netflix does have a few other movies joining this week.â€œMohawkâ€ is probably your best bet. Itâ€™s a horror movie that focuses on a violent cat-and-mouse game between Native Americans and members of the early American military.Another streaming option is â€œTAU,â€ a horror offering about humans who are forced to help an AI computer get smarter by completing painful tasks. With hope of escape diminishing, the captives try to fight back against their robot captor.Â Check out the trailer for â€œStar Wars: The Last Jediâ€ below (although youâ€™ve likely already seen it, as the YouTube version alone has over 50 million views).And if you want to stay informed about whatâ€™s joining Netflix on a weekly basis, make sure toÂ subscribe to the Streamline newsletter.Â This is part ofÂ Streamline, HuffPostâ€™s weekly recommendation service for streaming shows and movies. Every Saturday, Streamline ranks the best shows to watch online, including a focus onÂ Netflix.Â â€œStar Wars: The Last Jediâ€ | June 26Premise: A political faction called the Resistance is struggling to survive, while their enemy, the First Order, reigns supreme.With the Resistance on the brink of decimation, a long-shot effort is made to convince an old war hero to come join the fight.The lines of good and evil eventually become blurred in this battle and multiple characters question what theyâ€™re even fighting for.Is it actually good? Yes.There have been hilarious efforts to claim this movie is terrible. (An especially funny example is the â€œRemake The Last Jediâ€ campaign featured in the tweet below.)ButÂ â€œThe Last Jediâ€ is easily one of the best â€œStar Warsâ€ movies in the franchise. Itâ€™s the only one that truly rises to seek answers to the philosophical questions so many have looked to these movies for in the past. What is the nature of good and evil in war? How should religion inform a well-lived life? Is a world with extreme haves and have-nots morally corrupt?As with all of the â€œStar Warsâ€ movies, there are minor problems, of course. Characters act like idiotic children too often. Elements of the plot donâ€™t hold up with much scrutiny.Still, this is an extremely fun and thoughtful movie. So many scenes are beautifully shot. The action sequences are thrilling. Despite the long runtime, itâ€™s a movie well worth watching.Runtime: 2 hours, 32 minutesHereâ€™s the trailer ...June 26Â June 29Â Â June 30

Both Democrats and Republicans are pushing back against recent remarks made by Rep.Â Maxine WatersÂ (D-Calif.).At a Los Angeles rally on Saturday, Waters warned members of Trumpâ€™s Cabinet to be prepared for an onslaught of outrageÂ wherever they go should they continue to support the administrationâ€™s controversial zero toleranceÂ policy on undocumented immigrants.â€œYou think weâ€™re rallying now? You ainâ€™t seen nothing yet,â€ said Waters, whose remarks came one day after White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders was asked to leave a Virginia restaurant because of her role in the Trump administration. â€œAlready you have members of your Cabinet that are being booed out of restaurants ...Â protesters taking up at their house saying â€˜no peace, no sleep.â€™â€Waters took it a step further to encourage rally attendees to â€œmake sure we show up wherever we have to show up.â€â€œIf you see anybody from that Cabinet in a restaurant, in a department store, at a gasoline station, you get out and you create a crowd and you push back on them and you tell them theyâ€™re not welcome anymore, anywhere,â€ the congresswoman said.Over the weekend, Sanders tweeted about getting kicked out of The Red Hen in Lexington, Virginia, after the owner said she had concerns about serving someone affiliated with the administration. In recent weeks, senior adviser Stephen Miller and Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen NielsenÂ were also confronted while dining.The incident involving Sanders and Watersâ€™ response to it are now creating a larger conversation about civility and its place in politics.On Sunday, â€œThe Viewâ€ host Meghan McCain called Watersâ€™ impassioned speechÂ â€œextremely dangerous.â€â€œThis is absolutely insane,â€ McCain tweeted, later inciting the famous former FLOTUS Michelle Obama quote: â€œDonâ€™t ever again give me any of the â€˜when they go low, we go highâ€™ lip service.â€McCainâ€™s sentiments were echoed by many members of the GOP and several journalists onÂ a panel on CNNÂ Monday morning.RealClearPolitics editor A.B. Stoddard said Waters is â€œdoing everything she can to prevent her own promotionâ€ as chair of the Financial Services Committee.â€œThis is beyond overreach,â€ Stoddard said during the panel of her comments. â€œIt is so outrageous that she is trying to motivate voters on her side to be as divisive as President Trump. I just find it really unbelievable that this is the kind of thing theyâ€™re trying to stoke this mob mentality on the left. Itâ€™s the exact thing that will drive turnout on the other side.â€White House reporter Brian Karem, who has gone head-to-head with Sanders before,Â said he â€œwould have served her.â€â€œWhat happened to just a little bit of civility?â€ he asked.On Monday, House Minority Leader Rep.Â Nancy PelosiÂ (D-CA)Â added fuel to that fire and tweeted that while Watersâ€™ response to the incident might have been predictable, itâ€™s â€œunacceptable.â€Â President Donald Trump tweeted in response to Watersâ€™ remarks on Monday, calling the congresswoman an â€œextraordinarily low IQ person.â€ He also suggested Waters encouraged people to harm his supporters, when she did not.Sen. Chuck SchumerÂ (D-N.Y.) said Monday on the House floor that he â€œstronglyâ€ disagrees â€œwith those who advocate harassing folks who disagree with you.â€â€œNo one should call for the harassment of political opponents,â€ he said.When discussing the Red Hen incident on CBSâ€™ â€œFace the Nationâ€ Sunday, Rep. Elijah Cummings (D-Md.) said he thinks the Virginia restaurant owner should have served Sanders.Cummings did not mention Waters specifically but discussed his disapproval for the current incivility in politics.â€œThis tone is horrible. But again, I think President Trump has created this,â€ Cummings said. â€œSince he became president and even before, he has basically given people license to state things that are ugly.â€This article has been updated with comment from Schumer.Â

Maryland enacted a wide-reaching package of gun violence prevention laws last week, becoming one of just a handful of states to get behind little-known measures that could save hundreds of lives and millions of dollars.The measure, the Public Safety and Violence Prevention Act of 2018, was designed to address urban violence, an issue that gets relatively little attention in the U.S. gun debateÂ â€” itâ€™s the mass shootings like Newtown, Las Vegas and Parkland that make the headlines â€” despite accounting for most of the 13,000 firearm homicides and 60,000 nonfatal shootings that take place across the nation each year. The bill sets aside $5 million in the coming year to fund grants for programs that have been effective at making violence-stricken neighborhoods more peaceful.Maryland is now one of just six states funding gun violence prevention and intervention programs. California, Connecticut, Illinois, Massachusetts and New York have been making modest investments for a number of years, and data suggest it has paid off in target cities, with substantial declines in shootings and violent crime, according to a recent report by the Giffords Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence, a national nonprofit founded by former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords (D-Ariz.).The sponsor of the Maryland legislation, Democratic Delegate Brooke Lierman, said she felt compelled to act amid a murder epidemic in Baltimore, which saw more than 1,000 homicidesÂ from 2015 to 2017.â€œWhatâ€™s happening in Baltimore is a tragedy, as is whatâ€™s happening in other areas of the country where we are seeing homicide after homicide, death after death, day in and day out,â€Â she told HuffPost. â€œEvery dollar that we spend to prevent those deaths is definitely a dollar worth spending.â€Baltimore has alreadyÂ seen success with a prevention model called Cure Violence, a public health strategy that addresses the causes of violence. Case workers provide street outreach to those at risk of becoming victims or perpetrators of gun violence and mediate conflicts before they boil over. Neighborhoods that have adopted the program have seen far fewer shootings, with some recording periods of more than a year without a homicide, Lierman said.Anti-violence advocates say contributing to these programs makes financial sense. Gun violence costs the U.S. an estimated $229 billion each year, according to a 2012 study that measured direct spending on law enforcement, criminal justice and health care as well as indirect costs like lost wages and the effects of shootings on victimsâ€™ quality of life.Taxpayers often end up picking up a substantial portion of the tab for this violence.Â Many shooting victims donâ€™t have private health insurance, and itâ€™s expensive to prosecute and imprison perpetrators.Previous studies have calculated that taxpayers shoulder an average of $464,000 in costs for each gun homicide and as much as $40,000 for each nonfatal shooting. In Maryland, gun violence costs taxpayers approximately $294 million every year, according to an estimate by Giffords based on those studies.Supporters of this type of state-level initiative recognize that the problem of daily gun violence tends to be confined to cities, often to specific neighborhoods. But for people outside those areas, ignoring the issue comes at a cost too.â€œEven if you live in a suburban neighborhood where gun violence isnâ€™t affecting you day to day, you are directly paying for the gun violence in nearby cities,â€ said Mike McLively, the director of the Urban Gun Violence Initiative at Giffords. â€œIf you canâ€™t get on board for moral reasons, you should at least be able to get on board for economic reasons.â€But the fact that there has been so little support for and attention paid to prevention programs reveals a lot about the gun debate. Urban communities, particularly communities of color, face a shockingly disproportionate share of gun violence in the U.S.Of the 13,000 victims of gun homicides in 2015, over 8,500 were men of color, according to the Giffords report. Black men account for nearly half of firearm homicide victims each year but make up only 6 percent of the population. This phenomenon, known as murder inequality, is one of the many racial disparities that plague urban neighborhoods in the form of poverty, lack of employment opportunity and disinvestment in education and social services.Despite those figures, the mass shootings in affluent, predominantly white communities like Newtown,Â Connecticut, and Parkland,Â Florida, most frequently drive the conversation as well as the ensuing policy agenda on gun violence.With those isolated tragedies in mind, it makes sense that some people support tightening gun laws and restricting access to certain weapons as a response.Â In communities like Newtown, where there hasnâ€™t been a murder since the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting in 2012, according to federal data,Â and Parkland, which hadnâ€™t seen a gun homicide for at least a decade before the February shooting, a mass shooting may be residentsâ€™Â only experience with gun violence.There is disagreement overÂ how effective certain popular gun control proposals would be at preventing mass shootings. But it seems unlikely that a measure like banning bump stocks would do much to stem the routine bloodshed in cities, where most lives are being lost.This doesnâ€™t mean state lawmakers shouldnâ€™t continue to advocate for stronger gun laws as part of a comprehensive approach to preventing violence, said Lierman, who supported the complete package of firearms legislation in Maryland. But in states where gun politics is more contentious,Â she said, a plan like hers could give legislators a way to make a dent in violence without having to wade into a debate about gun control.â€œIt has absolutely nothing to do with taking away guns, and it should be exactly the kind of initiative that everybody, including gun enthusiasts, can support,â€ she said. â€œIt is all about creating programs to stop gun violence.â€At a committee hearing for Liermanâ€™s bill in February, pro-gun-rights lobbyists found reasons to oppose the effort.The NRA would be â€œmore comfortable if there were language included that recognizes the individual right to keep and bear arms,â€ a representative for the NRAâ€™s Institute for Legislative Action said during testimony. She said the organization couldnâ€™t commit to supporting the bill even if it were amended in that manner.John Jocelyn of the NRA-affiliated Associated Gun Clubs of Baltimore criticized the legislation for placing too much focus on the issue of violence with firearms and not enough on issues like â€œrebuilding families.â€â€œThe program in itself canâ€™t succeed unless we address the foundation issues to begin with,â€Â he said. He went on to encourage lawmakers to reintroduce the bill in a future session, when they could â€œaddress the entire massive problem we face.â€They were the lone opposing voices.â€œI was disappointed but not surprised,â€ said Lierman. â€œThe NRA has apparently decided it needs to oppose anything that has to do with decreasing gun violence.â€

Firearm enthusiasts and protesters are expected to gather in downtown Dallas on Friday for the beginning of the National Rifle Associationâ€™s Annual Meetings â€• a hotly politicized three-day event filled with high-profile speeches, educational seminars and, of course, lots of guns.Itâ€™s an opportune moment for the convention, now in its 147th year, as the NRA looks to rally gun-rights supporters who find themselves on the defensive amid a heated debate about firearms in America.Thatâ€™s something of an unfamiliar position for the nationâ€™s leading gun group. Political enthusiasm for gun reform has typically ebbed and flowed in the past, but the momentum appears to have shifted somewhat against the NRA in recent months, following a year of bloody mass shootings in places like Las Vegas and Parkland, Florida.Support for stricter gun laws reached 67 percent in March, the highest level in 25 years, according to Gallup â€• though more recent surveys suggest the energy may be starting to taper off.Survivors of the February massacre at Parklandâ€™s Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School have emerged as the face of the resurgent movement, whose members have been quick to portray the NRA as public enemy No. 1 in their campaign for stronger gun laws. The father of one of the slain students is slated to appear at a protest against the NRA in Dallas on Saturday.President Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence are scheduled to appear at the convention on Friday and address a forum for the NRAâ€™s Institute for Legal Action, the organizationâ€™s lobbying arm. Sens. Ted Cruz and John Cornyn, both Republicans from Texas, are also speaking at the gathering, as are Texas Gov. Greg Abbott (R) and a number of top NRA officials.Trumpâ€™s speech on Friday will mark his fourth consecutive appearance at the NRAâ€™s annual conference. Last year, he became the first sitting president to attend the confab since Ronald Reagan in 1983.Attendees of the NRA convention will have the weekend to check out firearms, ammunition and accessories from more than 800 companies, partake in an instructional seminar on concealed carry and get a book signed by former Milwaukee Sheriff David Clarke. A number of country music acts will also be on hand, including the Charlie Daniels Band, Travis Tritt and the Randy Rogers Band.The NRA says 80,000 members will be in Dallas for the gathering, which itâ€™s billing as the largest in the eventâ€™s history.The tone will likely be different outside Dallasâ€™ Kay Bailey Hutchison Convention Center, where national gun violence prevention groups and other local activist organizations plan to hold protests throughout the weekend.The counterprogramming includes a â€œdie-inâ€ demonstration on Friday evening, and a student-led rally on Saturday in support of a universal background check law and a ban on bump stocks and high-capacity ammunition magazines.A separate event on Saturday at Belo Garden Park, a few blocks from the convention center,Â is expected to feature actress Alyssa Milano and Fred Guttenberg, whose 14-year-old daughter, Jaime, was killed in the shooting at Stoneman Douglas.At his speech last year, Trump vowed to â€œcome throughâ€ for the NRA, which spent over $11 million in support of his presidential campaign and nearly $20 million more to attack his rival, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. After briefly hinting that he might be willing to defy the NRA and support changes to gun laws in the wake of the Parkland shooting, Trump met privately with the groupâ€™s leaders at the White House in March and reaffirmed his allegiance.But Trump has yet to deliver on the promise he made to the NRA faithful last year. After the 2016 election, the NRA had high hopes that Republicans in control of the White House and Congress would be able to deliver on two key priorities: eliminating federal regulations on the sale of gun silencers, also known as suppressors, and passing a concealed-carry reciprocity law, which would allow handgun owners in more gun-friendly states to carry their firearms in states with more restrictive laws.Neither of those measures has progressed, nor has any other gun legislation at the federal level. Meanwhile, there has been some movement on gun control at the state level with efforts to ban bump stocks â€• accessories that allow semiautomatic rifles to simulate automatic fire â€• and to pass â€œred flagâ€ laws, which give police more power to confiscate weapons from individuals deemed a threat to themselves or others.

The school shooting that took place in Parkland, Florida, earlier this year launched a new generation of gun control activists, inspired walkouts and marches, and sparked the most substantial â€• and long-lasting â€• shift in public opinion on guns in recent years. The appetite for gun control appears to have tapered off in the following weeks, but some surveys indicate that some changes in public opinion could endure.Â In the more than two months since that shooting, HuffPost and YouGov have conducted five surveys tracking Americansâ€™ views on guns. The results show a burst of support for gun reform in the two weeks after the shooting, followed by aÂ gradual reversion to the mean. Once-heightened concerns about gun violence have tapered back to previous levels, as has a desire for stricter gun laws and a belief that gun restrictions can be passed without violating Second Amendment rights.A few changes in thought, however, seem to have stuck. The percentage of Americans who believe itâ€™s politically possible to pass gun laws has dropped several points since its high in late February, but itâ€™s still higher than it was in the aftermath of last yearâ€™s massacres in Las Vegas and Sutherland Springs, Texas.In the most recent survey, one-fifth of Americans also chose gun policies as one of the two issues they found most important. That remains a noticeable, if modest, uptick from the 13 percent who chose it as a priority following the shooting in Sutherland Springs. Other polling since the Parkland shooting also suggested gun controlÂ was carrying greater-than-usual prominence on the campaign trail, although itâ€™s unclear how much of that energy will remain until November.That public opinion shifted at all in the wake of the shooting was striking. Itâ€™s even more striking that it lasted as long as it did. Last yearâ€™s shootings, by contrast, appeared to have little effect on Americansâ€™ views about guns.One illustration of the uncommon nature of this yearâ€™s debate comes from Google Trends, which tracks the level interest in various search terms. According to that data, searches for â€œmass shootingâ€ usually dwarf searches for â€œgun controlâ€ in the aftermath of an incident,Â and both disappear soon after. After the Parkland shooting, though, interest in gun control significantly outpaced attention to the shooting itself.Even now, specific gun reform proposals remain broadly popular. In the most recent survey, conducted in mid-April, three-quarters of Americans favored strengthening background checks,Â while just 13 percent opposed the proposal. A 63 percent majority favored raising the age for gun purchases to 21, with only about one-quarter in opposition. And a 42 percent plurality of those polled said President Donald Trump was not doing enough to pass new gun laws, while about one-quarter said heâ€™s doing the right amount. Just 9 percent that heâ€™s doing too much. (At the end of February, 37 percent said Trump wasnâ€™t doing enough.)Data from other pollsters, meanwhile, suggests that the national focus on guns is waning. But some find that the decline has stopped short of entirely erasing the changes post-Parkland.Some of the most granular information comes from the progressive pollster Civiqs, which has been tracking data on gun control for several years. According to its data, votersâ€™ backing for such restrictions spiked from the low 50s prior to the Parkland shooting to a high of 60 percent â€• a bigger reaction than in the wake of mass shootings in Charleston, South Carolina; San Bernardino, California; Orlando, Florida; Las Vegas and Sutherland Springs. Some of that change wore off in the weeks after, stabilizing around the 55 percent mark.Civiqsâ€™ data only goes back through 2015. But support for enacting new gun laws in April was higher than it was after the shooting at a Newtown, Connecticut, elementary school in 2012, according to a Washington Post/ABC News survey, thanks largely to a movement among Democratic-leaning groups. A 53 percent majority of Americans told pollsters they believed student activism on guns were part of a lasting movement, while 43 percent said the rallies were â€œmore of a one-time thing.â€Another poll from Gallup found that the share of Americans mentioning guns or gun control as the nationâ€™s most important problem dropped from 13 percent in March to 6 percent in April â€• a downtick that nevertheless leaves it as one of the highest-ranked national issues. In a recent NPR/PBS NewsHour Marist poll, a slim 53 percent majority of Democratic voters said guns will be a major factor for them in November, down 21 points since February. â€œThis finding raises a cautionary flag for voters who want gun policy to be front and center this election cycle,â€ Marist polling director Lee Miringoff told NPR.Use the widget below to further explore the results of the most recent HuffPost/YouGov survey, using the menu at the top to select survey questions and the buttons at the bottom to filter the data by subgroups:

In the years before he allegedly shot up a Tennessee Waffle House last Sunday, Travis Reinking, 29, told police that Taylor Swift was stalking him. He said he heard people barking like dogs. He told his family he wanted to kill himself. He was also a legal gun owner known to carry around an AR-15 rifle.By the time he was arrested at the White House in July 2017 for breaching an outer barrier of the complex and demanding to meet the president, Reinking had established a pattern of erratic and sometimes violent behavior. If someone had looked for signs of an individual who might be unfit to own a firearm, Reinking exhibited red flag upon red flag.After his arrest last year, Reinking was sentenced to 32 hours of community service on a misdemeanor charge of unlawful entry. But federal officials also thought his guns might be a problem.The FBI and Secret Service contacted law enforcement in Reinkingâ€™s home state of Illinois and convinced them to revoke his gun license, known as a firearm ownerâ€™s identification or FOID, and to confiscate four firearms and a cache of ammunition. A spokesperson for the FBI declined to comment on the specifics of that request, citing an open investigation.Once police obtained the guns, they turned them over to Reinkingâ€™s father, Jeffrey, a licensed gun owner. He â€œwas advised that he needed to keep the weapons secure and away from Travis,â€ a police report said. Yet at some point, the father has since told police, he returned the guns to his son. According to law enforcement, Reinking used one of those firearms, the AR-15, to kill four people and injure several more inside a Waffle House restaurant near Nashville on April 22.Reinkingâ€™s possession of that rifle underscores a larger issue: the difficulty of removing guns from people who are legally prohibited from owning them.â€œThis is one of the glaring gaps in our nationâ€™s firearm laws,â€ said Ari Freilich, staff attorney at the Giffords Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence. â€œIn most cases, when someone becomes prohibited from owning a gun for any reason, we donâ€™t have many mechanisms in place to make them relinquish their guns.â€Under federal law, certain people are not allowed to own guns. That includes anyone convicted of a felony or a domestic violence misdemeanor and anyone â€œadjudicated as a mental defectiveâ€ or â€œcommitted to any mental institution.â€ Many states have similar laws on the books.Generally, once a person is prohibited from having guns, theyâ€™ll be notified that itâ€™s illegal for them to remain armed, and their name will be flagged in the federal background check system to stop future purchases. But the process of physically removing firearms they already own â€• called relinquishment â€•Â varies depending on the state.The system almost worked in Illinois, which has some of the strongest gun laws in the country. The state requires background checks on all gun sales, and gun owners must have a permit. It is also one of the rare states with a procedure in place to remove guns from individuals once they lose the right to own them.But the law has a weakness: It allows people who cannot own guns to pass them along to anyone with a valid gun license, even relatives who live in the same house.â€œWhen somebodyâ€™s guns are taken by police because their FOID card is revoked, they only lose the right to possess those firearms. They donâ€™t lose title or ownership interest in those firearms,â€ explained Brendan Bukalski, an Illinois criminal defense attorney. â€œUnder Illinois law, that person gets to designate who they want to have the firearms given to.â€Itâ€™s common for states to allow prohibited individuals to transfer their firearms to a third party,Â who may then let those guns fall right back into the wrong hands, Freilich said.â€œIn too many cases, those closest to the person are unable or unwilling to keep guns out of their hands,â€ he said. The better practice is to mandate that relinquished firearms go to law enforcement or a licensed gun dealer.California is a leader in this area. In 2016, the state passed a law by ballot initiative that requires anyone convicted of a firearm-prohibiting crime â€• such as felonies, illegal weapons use or misdemeanors involving domestic abuse â€• to provide receipts showing that they sold or transferred their firearms to a licensed gun dealer or law enforcement agency within a specified time period. Enforcing these rules can be a challenge, however, and California authorities have been struggling to clear a backlog of prohibited individuals who may still own guns.William Rosen, deputy legal director for advocacy group Everytown for Gun Safety, said that even though Illinois law ultimately didnâ€™t prevent the shooting in Tennessee, itâ€™s essential for states to have a process for flagging dangerous people and revoking their access to firearms.â€œIn most states, there are no laws on the books that would prohibit even someone with all of these obvious warning signs of dangerousness,â€ he said.Removing guns from those who arenâ€™t supposed to have them has been a high priority for domestic violence activists for years. Only 17 states require people under final restraining orders for domestic violence to turn in their firearms once theyâ€™re prohibited from owning them. States that do so have lower rates of intimate partner homicide.Taking firearms away from individuals deemed to be a risk is also a key component of â€œred flag laws,â€ which have picked up steam in the wake of the Feb. 14 school shooting in Parkland, Florida.Red flag laws, also called gun violence restraining orders or GVROs, allow family members and law enforcement to petition a court to temporarily remove firearms from a person who is believed to be a danger to themselves or others, even if they havenâ€™t been convicted of a crime.The gunman who killed 17 inside Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School was well-known to local police for his disturbing and threatening behavior. But they had no power to confiscate his firearms because he had not been convicted or even charged with a crime.Florida passed a red flag law after the Parkland massacre, as have Vermont and Maryland. At least 25 other states and the District of Columbia have considered similar bills this year.Illinois doesnâ€™t have a red flag law, but state lawmakers are debating such legislation. Following the Tennessee shooting,Â the legislature is reportedly considering a provision that would prohibit people forced to relinquish firearms under this process from transferring those weapons to relatives.A separateÂ 2013 Illinois law requires physicians, psychologists, law enforcement officials and school administrators to report to state police if they believe a person poses a â€œclear and present dangerâ€ to themselves or others, so their gun license can be revoked.Police reports obtained by HuffPost reveal a string of troubling incidents involving Reinking in the years before the shooting. Law enforcement knew he was armed and had expressed unstable and suicidal thoughts.â€œTravis is hostile towards police and does not recognize police authority. Travis also possesses several firearms,â€ a Tazewell County, Illinois, sheriffâ€™s deputy wrote in a May 2016 report, after responding to what was documented as a â€œsuicide attempt by firearms.â€ Police ended up taking Reinking against his will to a nearby hospital for evaluation.â€œTravis has some mental problems and I asked him if he would like to speak to [medical personnel] but he stated he didnâ€™t want to. Travis had already spoke to them before and been in the hospital,â€ an officer wrote in a June 2017 report, following an episode in which Reinking had allegedly brandished his AR-15 in front of employees of his fatherâ€™s company.Still, it wasnâ€™t until Reinkingâ€™s arrest at the White House that authorities finally decided he might not be suited for firearms ownership. Unfortunately, his father didnâ€™t appear to agree with their determination.

Major media outlets urgently call for gun control as President Trump stresses the need to address America's mental health issues; reaction from Jamie Weinstein, host of the 'Jamie Weinstein Show' on National Review, and Ethan Bearman, radio talk host show and author.Gun control advocates are only too sure that they occupy the moral high ground. In the aftermath of the Parkland, Florida high school shooting that left 17 dead, they are accusing their opponents of having â€œblood on their hands.â€Itâ€™s no longer just activists such as Chelsea Handler who are spewing such vitriol. Even mainstream liberals such as political scientist Norm Ornstein use the phrase.Gun control advocatesâ€™ new hot number is that there have been 18 school shootings so far this year, but this is a gross exaggeration.To get 18, one has to count all instances from kindergarten through college where a gun was fired on or near school property. This includes a case of a police officer accidentally discharging his gun, as well as suicides â€“ such as that of a 31-year-old military veteran with no connection to the school who killed himself in the school parking lot.Excluding suicides, there have only been five cases where someone was actually shot at a K-12 school. Four actually involved a gun being fired on school property, and two of those resulted in fatalities.In fact, gun control advocatesâ€™ proposals would do more harm than good. They are the ones opposing life-saving laws.Every time there's a mass public shooting, gun control advocates call for more background checks. President Obama did so each time he spoke after a mass public shooting. Gun control advocates like to think this is a magic solution that would have prevented Wednesdayâ€™s massacre.The proposed background check laws wouldn't have prevented the attack in Florida, nor any other mass public shooting thatâ€™s happened in the 21st century.But the background checks come at a real cost, ranging from $55 in Oregon to $125 in New York City and Washington, D.C.With millions of mistaken denials because of â€œfalse positives,â€ the checks have confused the names of law-abiding good citizens with those who really are prohibited from owning guns. It is the most vulnerable people â€“ poor minorities â€“ who are kept from being able to protect themselves and their families.Some, such as Sen. Bill Nelson, D-Fla., reacted to Wednesdayâ€™s attack by immediately decrying the failure to keep people on the terrorist watch list from buying guns.But many on the terrorist watch list are not suspected of being terrorist threats, and of the 2,000 people who have bought guns, not a single one has been accused of using a gun in a crime. The bill prohibiting such purchases never got passed because the Democrats didnâ€™t want to pass it.Sen. John Cornyn, R-Texas, offered an alternative. Under his proposal, the U.S. attorney general could deny a person on the terrorist watch list the ability to purchase a gun, but would need to prove probable cause within 72 hours. Otherwise, some unnamed government bureaucrat could arbitrarily add a person to the terror list and the person would lose his right to self-defense.Democrats said that the time limit was too short. But instead of proposing a longer time period, they fought against any judicial review.Others mention a new assault weapon ban, but even research funded by the Clinton administration concluded that the previous ban and limit on magazine size had â€œno discernible reduction in the lethality and injuriousness of gun violence.â€Those who are blaming the Florida attack on large capacity magazines that can hold more bullets donâ€™t understand how quickly magazines can be changed or how incredibly easy they are to make.But while Democrats keep pushing for gun control laws that wonâ€™t help, they wonâ€™t discuss the one change that might have made a difference: abolishing gun-free zones, where the defenselessness of general citizens is guaranteed by law.It is hard to ignore that all the mass public shootings in Florida â€“ including the Orlando nightclub, the Orlando RV business, the Fort Lauderdale Airport, the Hialeah restaurant, as well as Wednesdayâ€™s at the high school â€“ were places where guns are banned.Nationwide, over 98 percent of such mass shootings attacks since 1950 have also been in gun-free zones.These killers might be crazy, but they arenâ€™t stupid. They want to kill as many people as possible. Killers in attacks â€“ including the Charleston church, the Colorado â€œBatmanâ€ movie theater and Santa Barbara, California â€“ explained that they picked defenseless targets where they knew no one would have a gun.What is interesting is that even though gun control advocates are refusing the types of policies that will really save lives, they are claiming that others â€œhave blood on their hands.â€ That same language hasnâ€™t been used against them. Maybe it should be.John R. Lott, Jr. is a columnist forÂ FoxNews.com. He is an economist and was formerly chief economist at the United States Sentencing Commission. Lott is also a leading expert on guns and op-eds on that issue are done in conjunction with the Crime Prevention Research Center. He is the author of nine books including "More Guns, Less Crime." His latest book is "The War on Guns: Arming Yourself Against Gun Control Lies (August 1, 2016). Follow him on Twitter@johnrlottjr.

Press secretary pays tribute to victims' acts of heroism, says American spirit cannot and will not be broken.White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders on Monday chided congressional Democrats -- and Hillary Clinton -- for sounding the call for gun control within hours of the Las Vegas massacre.Â â€œThere is a time and a place for political debate but now is the time for the country to come together,â€ Sanders said at the daily briefing. â€œThis is an unspeakable tragedy. Today is a day for consoling survivors and mourning those who were lost.â€Sanders noted that the investigation into Sunday's attack is still ongoing, and a motive is yet to be determined.Â â€œIt is premature to discuss policy when we donâ€™t know all the facts,â€ Sanders said.Â Nevertheless, Clinton was out early Monday with a series of tweets going after the NRA and silencers -- questioning how much worse the massacre might have been if silencers had been used.â€œThe crowd fled at the sound of gunshots. Imagine the deaths if the shooter had a silencer which the NRA wants to make easier to get,â€ she tweeted. â€œOur grief isnâ€™t enough. We can and must put politics aside, stand up to the NRA, and work together to try to stop this from happening again.â€The crowd fled at the sound of gunshots. Imagine the deaths if the shooter had a silencer, which the NRA wants to make easier to get.Our grief isn't enough. We can and must put politics aside, stand up to the NRA, and work together to try to stop this from happening again.TRUMP, IN A SOMBER ADDRESS, CALLS LAS VEGAS SHOOTING AN 'ACT OF PURE EVIL'Clintonâ€™s comments seemed to reference the NRAâ€™s push to ease federal rules for silencers. She soon took heat from critics who called her remarks â€œignorantâ€ and â€œirrelevantâ€ -- noting silencers in this case probably would not been dampened the sound very much.Â Asked about Clinton's tweets, Sanders told reporters she hadnâ€™t spoken with the president on the issue, but underscored that the investigation into the massacre is ongoing.â€œI think before we start trying to talk about the preventions of what took place last night, we need to know more facts, and right now weâ€™re simply not at that point,â€ Sanders said. â€œIt is very easy for Mrs. Clinton to criticize and to come out, but I think we need to remember the only person with blood on their hands is that of the shooter, and this isnâ€™t a time for us to go after individuals or organizations. I think we can have those policy conversations, but today is not that day.â€The shooting at a country concert outside Las Vegasâ€™ Mandalay Bay resort left 58 people dead and more than 500 people hospitalized, making the horrific tragedy Â the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history. The shooter was identified as 64-year-old Stephen Paddock.Sanders told reporters that the president was briefed on the attack early Monday morning by his Chief of Staff John Kelly and has been updated â€œregularly and constantlyâ€ throughout the day.Â â€œIâ€™ve seen him today and I think he, like most of America, is saddened and certainly his heart and compassion goes out to those who are affected,â€ Sanders said. â€œToday is more a day of reflection, mourning, and gratefulness for those that were saved.â€But Sanders underscored the presidentâ€™s commitment to the Second Amendment, saying â€œheâ€™s been clearâ€ that he is a â€œsupporter,â€ and that likely has not changed.HILLARY CLINTON SLAMMED FOR 'IGNORANT' STATEMENT ON GUNS AFTER LAS VEGAS SHOOTINGThe shooting prompted swift calls from Democratic lawmakers for tighter gun legislation.Connecticutâ€™s Democratic senators, Chris Murphy and Richard Blumenthal, both issued statements calling for tighter gun laws on Monday.â€œItâ€™s time for Congress to get off its ass and do something,â€ Murphy said in a statement.When asked about Murphyâ€™s comments in the briefing, Sanders said she agreed that Congress â€œshould get up and do something,â€ taking a shot at the legislative branch for having â€œseveral monthsâ€ of â€œdoing very little.â€â€œWe donâ€™t want to try to create laws that wonâ€™t stop these types of things from happening,â€ Sanders said, citing the example of Chicago, a city with some of the â€œstrictest gun laws in the countryâ€ and some of the highest murder rates. â€œWhen that time comes, we have to look at things that may have real impact.â€Sanders on Monday also tackled the thorny subject of North Korea, backing up the president after he tweeted over the weekend telling his Secretary of State Rex Tillerson to stop wasting time negotiating with Kim Jong Un's regime.Â â€œI told Rex Tillerson, our wonderful Secretary of State, that he is wasting his time trying to negotiate with Little Rocket Man,â€ Trump tweeted Sunday. â€œSave your energy Rex, weâ€™ll do what has to be done!â€TRUMP: TALKING TO KIM JONG UN A WASTE, 'WILL DO WHAT NEEDS TO BE DONE'Â Sanders echoed the statements, saying they have put "diplomatic pressure" on the rogue nation, but "now is not the time to have conversations with North Korea."Brooke Singman is a Politics Reporter for Fox News. Follow her on Twitter at @brookefoxnews.

FILE -- Handguns are seen for sale in a display case.
                                    
                                        Â (REUTERS/Jim Young)
                                    
                                The mediaâ€™s pro-gun control bias doesnâ€™t just distort news coverage. TV networks have used their primetime entertainment shows to portray gun rights advocates as dishonest, extremist and unconcerned about the loss of innocent lives. At the same time, advocates of gun control are portrayed as caring, upstanding and responsible citizens.The gun control debate isnâ€™t portrayed as having two sides. Itâ€™s a morality play of good versus evil.NBC might be the worst network, but itâ€™s a tight race. It seems to have given marching orders to its TV writers to churn out scripts demonizing law-abiding gun owners and lionizing those who want to slap strict new controls on gun ownership, even if that means disregarding the Second Amendment to the Constitution.Recently the NBC show â€œTakenâ€ (Season 2, Episode 11) tried to convey to viewers that gun-free zones work because the criminals wonâ€™t disobey the bans.Santana (Jessica Camacho) asks Bryan Mills (Clive Standen), if he is â€œOK with this whole no-guns thing.â€ Mills replies that it is OK because the gun-free zone means that â€œbad guys wonâ€™t have them either.â€Do people really think that a group of paid, professional killers couldnâ€™t find some way to get guns into a hospital, a school or some other place just because a sign is posted saying guns are not allowed? Thereâ€™s no mention that over 98 percent of mass public shootings since 1950 have occurred in places where guns are banned. This is precisely because criminals prefer unarmed victims.About a month ago the NBC show â€œChicago Fireâ€ (Season 6, Episode 15) had a scene where stored ammunition catches fire. Bullets fly everywhere, seriously wounding one of the firefighters. The firefighters think that a sniper is targeting them. It is hard to believe that anyone would want to have a gun in their home after watching this scene.But the scene is complete fiction. A gun barrel is needed to harness a gunpowder explosion so a bullet can be propelled forward. Outside of a gun, the gunpowder in a bullet would simply explode in all directions, producing very little energy to actually push the bullet forward.A February episode of NBCâ€™s â€œThe Black Listâ€ (Season 5, Episode 13) begins with a group of people accusing a gun maker of providing inexpensive guns that â€œhave no value to anyone but criminals.â€ The gun maker is profiting â€œoff blood money,â€ because gun â€œsales drive up homicide rates.â€There is even a dig about how the law protects the gun maker from being sued for purposefully killing people. The gun sellerâ€™s only response is that everything he doing is perfectly legal. No one mentions that poor people, particularly poor minorities, are the most likely victims of violent crime and that they use inexpensive guns for self-defense.NBCâ€™s â€œChicago P.D.â€ shows no less egregious bias in an episode from February (Season 5, Episode 13). Gang members threaten a small business owner, who a police officer advises to leave his permitted concealed handgun at home.The owner doesnâ€™t follow the instructions and ends up killed by the gang members, his gunÂ lying next to his dead body. To leave nothing to viewersâ€™ imagination, a later scene shows surveillanceÂ camera footage of the businessman being beaten to death because he drew his gun on the gang members.You wouldn't know it from watching the show, but having a gun is the safest course of action when confronted by a criminal. The police canâ€™t be everywhere all the time to protect everyone. The only message is that the man would still be alive if he'd left his gun at home.Of course, NBC is hardly alone. In January, CBSâ€™ â€œHawaii 5-0â€ showed an unhinged concealed handgun permit holder unsuccessfully trying to kill someone. Later, the permit holder proudly proclaims to the police that it is alright for him to have his gun because of his permit.Of course, there is no mention that permit holders are incredibly law-abiding, or that they are convicted of firearms violations at even lower rates than police.In ABCâ€™s â€œDesignated Survivor,â€ the U.S. President (Kiefer Sutherland), takes a question from a woman whose daughter was killed by an ex-boyfriend whoâ€™d been in prison.
