Gabby Giffords (D-Ariz.).â€œGiven the failure of adults to protect kids, the kids are understandably suspicious of the adults, so itâ€™s really important that you approach young people as partners,â€ Ambler said,Â noting that students planned the March For Our Lives without being asked.Â Several of the gun control advocates emphasized that the student activists have already started to build a sustainable, long-term political movement. The urgency and personal nature of the issue, they said,Â is likely to continue to motivate young people.â€œThis active shooter generation, theyâ€™re coming of age â€” and theyâ€™re pissed,â€ Ambler said.Brown said frequent lockdown and mass shooter drills at schools around the country have shown kids what needs to change.Â â€œFor many kids, this is how they grew up, and itâ€™s a reminder, every time they go through it, of how little has been done to truly protect them,â€Â Brown said. â€œThe answer that the adults have put into place, they know, really, is not going to stop it from happening again.â€â€œI donâ€™t see them just walking away from this,â€Â she added. â€œThis is something thatâ€™s deeply personal, like, â€˜Youâ€™ve told me this is the way our government is supposed to work. I see that this is â€” pardon my French â€” a bastardization of it. Fix it, and if youâ€™re not going to fix it, then get out of the way.â€™â€A major motivator is studentsâ€™ visceral anger at â€œthe corruption of our political system,â€ as Ambler characterized it.â€œThe NRA is a really good bad guy for folks, and kids naturally understand that money in politics has had insidious effects on the direction that our country takes politically,â€ he said. â€œIt just seems obvious [to them].â€Kaplan noted that the Parkland studentsÂ have tried to make their movement inclusiveÂ and show just how many people are regularly affected by gun violence:Â They have put attention on shootings in urban areas where people of color predominantly live, and have spoken out about their own experiences in mostly white suburban areas.The studentsâ€™ â€œcomplete frustration and almost righteous indignationâ€ with the government, as Brown put it, has a recent historical parallel: activism against the Iraq War, which reshaped the Democratic Party and catalyzed a generation of progressive leaders.It is too early to say whether students motivated by gun violence now will go on to run for office, but Ambler said he sees the seeds being planted.â€œYouâ€™ve got a generation of Americans that is engaging politically for the very first time in their lives. We probably all remember that moment when politics became more significant for us, right?â€Â he said. â€œFor me, it was the Iraq War, when I was a senior in college, when I saw exactly how important political engagement was. I think for this generation, thatâ€™s happening through the lens of gun violence. The impact of that is going to ripple for years.â€Kaplan, who was also a college student during the anti-Iraq War movement, said she believes todayâ€™s students will stay active.â€œOnce young people start down this path, itâ€™s hard to get off of it,â€ she said. â€œI think theyâ€™ve already determined their commitment and what itâ€™s going to take to win, so really, itâ€™s in their hands.â€

The message at the March for Our Lives rally in WashingtonÂ this weekend was clear: Gun violence isnâ€™t just a problem of mass shootings like the one at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, last month. Nor is it isolated to the bloodshed that tears through cities on a daily basis, or to other routine shootings often tied to mental health, domestic violence or police intervention.Gun violence is an all of the above issue.As speakers took the stage on Saturday â€•Â none of them above the age of 19 â€• they offered differing perspectives on the many ways guns affect individuals and communities alike.This diversity shouldnâ€™t have come as a shock to anyone following the Stoneman Douglas students as they prepared for the event. In the lead-up to the rally,Â theyÂ spoke out about their own privilege and the need to broaden their scope beyond the mass shootings that rarely, but explosively, strike affluent communities like theirs. They met with students from Chicago and WashingtonÂ to discuss what gun violence looks like to them, and how best to confront it.The lineup of speakers seemed like proof the Parkland students werenâ€™t just talking the talk. They had worked to make their movement genuinely inclusive, both in terms of race and socioeconomic class,Â and in its embodiment of the varied experiences of gun violence around the nation.But now comes the hard part for the March for Our Lives movement. As it evolves beyond activism and into more concrete advocacy,Â the students face the challenge of crafting an agenda that continues to embrace inclusivity while working toward solutions to tackle gun violence in all of its forms.â€œGun violence is such a local issue,â€ said Paul John, leader of the New York City chapter of Million Hoodies, a racial justice group. â€œWhereas some communities may have more of an issue with domestic violence, certain suburbs may have been impacted my mass shootings, others by suicide.â€Each of those problems requires a different set of tools to address. When it comes to urban gun violence in particular, which accounts for a disproportionate share of overall shootings,Â it can be a challenge to get people outside the affected communities to understand how pervasive and deeply intertwined the issue is with other structural inequities that have long plagued inner-city neighborhoods, John said.â€œItâ€™s going to be important for the young Parkland students to realize how complex gun violence really is and take steps toward being more informed as to how gun violence affects communities around the country,â€ he said.The March For Our Lives campaign has already identified a number of policy objectives, including universal background checks for gun purchases and a ban on assault weapons like the AR-15 style rifle used in Parkland. But to those who have been actively involved in community-based gun violence prevention efforts, prescriptions like these are far from a catch-all.â€œWe all agree gun laws are a good start, but we really need to look more comprehensively at what it is that causes people to act out violently,â€ said Miguel Dominguez, director of youth programs at Community Coalition, a social justice nonprofit in Los Angeles.Lamar Johnson, the violence prevention coordinator for BRAVE (Bold Resistance Against Violence Everywhere), based out of St. Sabina Parish in Chicago,Â sees it similarly.â€œWe have legislation and we have tough gun laws, but what we donâ€™t have is investment in our community,â€ he said.A decadeslong lack of investment in neighborhoods in Chicago and Los Angeles has helped feed a â€œculture of violence,â€Â said Johnson. With little funding for schools, businesses and social services, many local kids suffer from a lack of opportunity, which serves as a pipeline into the sorts of criminal activity that often leads to shootings.Both Community Coalition and BRAVE take a holistic approach to violence prevention, providing outreach to youth to give them the skills and resources they need to resist the traps that can lead them down these roads in the first place.Â Youth leaders from both organizations spoke on Saturday to offer a window into the realities they face. Edna Chavez, a 17-year-old from Los Angeles, recalled learning how to â€œduck from bulletsâ€ before she could read. Trevon Bosley, a 19-year-old from Chicago,Â reminded the crowd that â€œeveryday shootings are everyday problems.â€ Chavez and Bosley both lost brothers to gun violence.Johnson said he was happy to see those voices represented at the March for Our Lives, but he noted that initiatives like BRAVE need more than just a larger stage from which to tell their stories.â€œPeople figure they gave us a platform to speak so they did their due diligence, which is like a slap to the face, because giving me a microphone means nothing if youâ€™re not going to give me the funding and the resources for my youth program and violence prevention programs,â€ said Johnson.Â â€œWe still have to go back into this crime element we live in every day.â€Â St. Sabina has seen an uptick in calls from interested donors since Bosleyâ€™s speech, said Johnson. But so far, there have been no celebrities or high-dollar donations â€• no Oprah,Â or George and Amal Clooney, who together donated $1 million to the March for Our Lives.â€œWeâ€™re still pushing for that and we still need that and thatâ€™s why weâ€™re trying to publicize it as much as possible to say, itâ€™s not just in Chicago but in all the urban cities across America that have the same issues,â€ said Johnson.Johnson added that his BRAVE members have remained in touch with the Parkland students, and that theyâ€™ve discussed additional events for the summer, when violence in Chicago and in many cities tends to spike.The March for Our Lives students will need to continue actively fostering this collaboration if they want to keep their movement truly inclusive, said Amber Goodwin, founder and executive director of Community Justice Reform Coalition, a national advocacy group focused on gun violence prevention. Goodwin said this sort of cooperation will be mutually beneficial.â€œPlugging in with groups that are already doing the local work is really important,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s a great way to show partnership, but also to meet people where theyâ€™re already at, versus asking people to come to where folks in the gun violence prevention space have been for so long.â€A crucial part of this alliance will involve the Parkland kids simply listening to the concerns of other communities and using their input to inform the movementâ€™s agenda,Â said Goodwin.Â Policies can have different effects and connotations for different groups of people, and solutions that appeal to some may seem dangerous to others.That disparity was on display in Parkland this week, where a group of black Stoneman Douglas students spoke out,Â explaining that the increased police presence at school since the shooting made them uncomfortable.Â They also said they felt theyâ€™d been left out of conversations about the local response to the massacre.This sort of oversight has cropped up in the national gun violence prevention movement as well, said Goodwin, who previously worked for the gun control organization launched by former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords (D-Ariz.).Â She said many groups working on the issue beenÂ â€œsiloed,â€Â which has meant marginalized communities have sometimes not had â€œthe self-determination and the spaceâ€ to be able to advocate for their specific needs.The March for Our Lives was an all-too-rare example of what it looks like when these communities are given that opportunity, said Goodwin. She advised the Stoneman Douglas students to continue reaching out toÂ elected officials and organizations that center communities of color, and to take advantage of existing local partnerships and gun violence prevention programs that have already shown tangible results.â€œThis has to be an intersectional issue,â€ said Goodwin. â€œBut itâ€™s not just a matter of saying that things are not diverse and that we need diversity and inclusion; itâ€™s actually going to be dismantling a lot of the systems that have been built.â€That wonâ€™t be an easy task, Goodwin admits,Â which is one reason she believes the young organizers behind March for Our Lives shouldnâ€™t be afraid to lean on adults for their experience and expertise.â€œYes, young people should lead, but we should be thinking about how we do this inter-generationally, where weâ€™re looking at the strategies that have worked for more seasoned organizers,â€ she said.But even if the March for Our Lives students do dedicate themselves to building and strengthening these sort of partnerships, many of the obstacles for local gun violence prevention efforts will remain. Getting the necessary resources and support needed for them to succeed is a constant struggle, said Paul of Million Hoodies.â€œMany times, the local governments are strapped for funding to implement these strategies ... so being able to bring in private funding and being able to bring in people who are looking to support gun violence prevention organizations on a consistent basis is key,â€ he said.With a massive platform, the March for Our Lives organizers may be able to help channel resources toward those initiatives.Another way the March for Our Lives movement can champion these causes is through the ballot.Â Organizers made a big push to register voters at the weekend rallies, and the Parkland students have made the November elections a key focal point in the movement.But activists want young people to know that itâ€™s not just a matter of backing members of Congress who support gun reform. Itâ€™s also about mayors, city councilmembers and other local officials who, in some ways, have more direct power to address gun violence in their communities.Although the Parkland students have a lot of work ahead to ensure that their movement can deliver on the promising vision laid out on Saturday, John is cautiously optimistic that theyâ€™ll be able to succeed where others have failed.â€œGeneration after generation, you see people become at least a little more radical in their thinking of how to change the world,â€Â he said. â€œThese young folks, I think, are much more willing to work together than Iâ€™ve seen historically in this movement.â€

The megaphone was heavy, the Florida sun was beating down on my face, and my knees were shaking uncontrollably. Meanwhile, my adrenaline was working overtime as I scanned the crowd for any signs of danger. My voice was hoarse from shouting from the podium and my heart was pounding.This was what change felt like, and I had never been prouder in my life.On March 2, I helped lead the community of students at Seminole High School in Sanford, Florida, who walked out of class in protest of the U.S. governmentâ€™s failure to undertake gun reform after the Parkland shooting.Located only a few hours upstate from Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, my school is attended by many students who personally knew people affected by the mass shooting in Parkland, Florida. Furthermore, weâ€™d lost an alum from our school at the Pulse nightclub massacre less than two years ago. Needless to say, we had had enough.Because, if weâ€™re being honest, teenagers are often overlooked, talked down to or ignored by our society. I was determined to change this attitude by inspiring my fellow students to embrace our potential as our countryâ€™s future leaders. The walkout, which initially existed as a rumor floating around campus, became a concrete event when I and several student activists took matters into our own hands. We formed a Snapchat group to coordinate our efforts. Social media was our secret weapon and most powerful tool in bringing together the student body.For a week, we planned. We met with our administration and enlisted the help of our cityâ€™s police to ensure the safety of all student protesters. Most importantly, we crafted the theme of our protest: not loud noise, but loud speech. Not empty anger, but deliberate change. Not embitterment, but empowerment.And so, my friend Mike and I printed 400 copies of letters addressed to our senator, Marco Rubio, and state representative, Jason Brodeur. In the letters, we included specific policies we wanted our leaders to support â€• including repealing the Dickey Amendment, reinstating the 1994 Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act, refusing ALEC legislation at the federal level, and ending the gun show loophole at the state level â€• to prove that we had done our research and that we meant business. At the bottom of each letter, we provided spaceÂ (and plenty of Sharpie markers!) for students to voice their concerns.We also hoped to honor the lives lost in Parkland and to stand in solidarity with the survivors of the shooting. Each of the organizers wore a black shirt bearing a picture of one of the victims.Â I chose to wear the face and name ofÂ Carmen Schentrup, a senior at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School. I had read that Carmen was a National Merit finalist, but her letter arrived the day after she died. Carmenâ€™s death felt like a personal loss to me, because next year I will be receiving my own National Merit letter â€• the same letter Carmen shouldâ€™ve gotten, but never will. And to me, that is unthinkable.In spite of our grief, Friday morning felt perfect: one of those bright, sunny, summer-vacation-in-Florida days that makes you feel like anything is possible. The hallways were bursting with excitement, the classrooms were flooded with students carrying signs and wearing orange. During our last organizersâ€™ meeting at lunchtime, the news vans arrived. When they werenâ€™t permitted to enter the school, they mounted their cameras on helicopters. To me, that felt like proof that our plan was working, because we had gotten peopleâ€™s attention. It was finally our moment.With 10 minutes left to go before the walkout, we tested out the megaphone one last time. We took a deep breath, reassured each other that everything would be fine, and climbed up onto a wall in our school courtyard. And then it was game on.All at once, students and teachers started pouring into the courtyard, coming out of classrooms and cafeterias, all of us proudly bearing our signs. Whenever I thought they had stopped arriving, another set of doors opened and another group of students burst out, and soon, the courtyard was filled. We did that, I remember thinking numbly. Weâ€™re all here.After a brief moment of silence in honor of the victims, my fellow activists spoke out to the crowd, using the megaphone that we had borrowed from the school band. One of my friends recited a spoken word poem, and another recited an open letter to Rubio. And then the megaphone was in my hand, and I was looking out at the crowd, and my knees began to shake because the possibility had just occurred to me that anyone could have a gun, but now wasnâ€™t the time to back down.I lifted up the megaphone and spoke my truth. â€œWe Vote Next,â€ which had been the rallying cry of my speech, was taken up by the entire crowd, because that kind of empowerment is contagious.I couldnâ€™t tell you what happened after that, even though my speech has since been featured all over studentsâ€™ social media. Really, all I remember is feeling more alive and in control than I ever had in my life. In that moment, I forgot that I was nervous and scared. In that moment, I felt bulletproof. I felt like the future.When the rally was over, the rest of the afternoon passed in a blur. I remember walking off campus to be interviewed by local TV stations. (My friends were later upset that the evening news had spelled my name wrong, but such is the struggle of being young, brown and woke.)Really, what I learned from the walkout was simple: Itâ€™s crucial to always stand up for what you believe in, and when you have a passion, you run â€• or in my case, walk â€• with it. True activism requires thought and deliberation, not just anger. And at the end of the day, together we are stronger than any bullet.We have to be.

Harley-Davidson Inc. announced it is shifting production of some of its motorcycles to Europe because of President Donald Trumpâ€™s escalating trade war, which critics warn could hamstring the humming U.S. economy and cost jobs.Trump hosted executives from the Milwaukee-based company and the union officials representing its workers last year at the White House. The president hailed the company as a model of American manufacturing, an industry he promised to restore. He further praised the executives â€œfor building things in Americaâ€ and predicted the company would expand its operations during his administration.Things arenâ€™t looking so great for the iconic motorcycle producer this year, however. The company said in a regulatory filing on Monday that retaliatory tariffs imposed on American exports by the European Union rose between 6 percent and 31 percent this year, resulting in a jump in $2,200 per average motorcycle exported to the EU.But rather than hike prices in the U.S., the company said it would absorb the cost in the short term â€•Â projected to be some $30 million to $45 million through this yearâ€• and shift some production to international factories in coming months.â€œIncreasing international production to alleviate the EU tariff burden is not the companyâ€™s preference, but represents the only sustainable option to make its motorcycles accessible to customers in the EU and maintain a viable business in Europe. Europe is a critical market for Harley-Davidson,â€ the company said in a statement.The move follows a round of layoffs at the companyâ€™s manufacturing plants in Milwaukee and Kansas City, Missouri, last year, costing 180 manufacturing jobs.Trump tweetedÂ MondayÂ that he was â€œsurprisedâ€ by Harley-Davidsonâ€™s decision to move some production overseas, urging the company to be â€œpatient.â€Trump on Friday furtherÂ threatened to escalate a trade warÂ with Europe by imposing a 20 percent tariff on all U.S. imports of EU-assembled cars.Republican leaders in Congress have so far resisted challenging Trump on trade, worrying that an intraparty clash could harm the party in Novemberâ€™s midterm elections. But there are signs that some members of the presidentâ€™s party â€• which historically has favored free trade â€• may finally be reaching a breaking point.Â Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.), for example, warned over the weekend that heâ€™s prepared to oppose Trumpâ€™s judicial nominees unless the Senate votes on legislation curtailing the presidentâ€™s power to unilaterally impose tariffs on other countries.â€œI think myself and a number of senators, at least a few of us, will stand up and say, â€˜Letâ€™s not move any more judges until we get a vote, for example, on tariffs,â€™â€ Flake, who is retiring this year, said on ABCâ€™s â€œThis Week.â€This story has been updated with Trumpâ€™s Monday tweet.

CNN White House correspondent Jim Acosta was heckled at President Donald Trumpâ€™s rally in South Carolina on Monday as members of the crowd chanted â€œGo home!â€ and â€œCNN sucks!â€Acosta was reportedly waiting in the press area at the rally in West Columbia, where the president was about to campaign for the stateâ€™s Republican Gov. Henry McMaster. But before Trump arrived, attendees holding signs reading â€œCNN fake newsâ€ began chanting for the reporter to leave the venue. At one point, a woman pointed at the journalist, repeating â€œTake him outâ€ and urging her fellow rally-goers to heckle him.Acosta attempted to shake the womanâ€™s hand, telling her he had a right to cover the event. He then said that he respected the United States as the woman waved her arms at him.â€œNo! You do not respect it,â€ the woman yelled.Acosta later addressed the event on CNN.â€œWhile we have had people come up to us and be nice, I did have an elderly woman come up to me just a short while ago,â€ he told CNNâ€™s Wolf Blitzer. â€œShe came up to me and said that we at CNN should get the â€˜fâ€™ out of this auditorium. She then turned to the crowd and whipped them up into a frenzy.â€He continued: â€œWe are here to do our jobs and report the news and report on this rally, and weâ€™re not going anywhere.â€Later in the evening, Trump began his speech on a familiar note, attacking the press and calling media outlets gathered at the rally â€œfake news,â€ a taunt that drew raucous boos and jeers.Â â€œThe enemy, the enemy of the people I call â€™em,â€Â the president said of the media.Despite his continued attacks on CNN, he appeared to set his sights on a new target following an exchange of barbs with late-night host Jimmy Fallon this week. â€œNBC is worse actually than CNN,â€ Trump quipped.Acosta has often earned the ire of the president and other White House officials, including press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders, over the past year. LeBron James Jr. will soon join his superstar father above the rim â€• but he isnâ€™t there just yet.The 13-year-old tried a dunk for the first time in a game over the weekend in the â€œBallinâ€™ on the Beachâ€ AAU tournament in Miami.He caught his dad by surprise. â€œMan what!?!?!â€ the future Hall of Famer wrote of the teen trying to complete one of basketballâ€™s rites of passage.â€œBronnyâ€ dribbled most of the floor and sprung up for a one-handed jam just like dad â€• but without stuffing the ball through the hoop. Netflix adds a movie youâ€™ve likely already seen this week. And if you havenâ€™t seen it, now is your chance to finally catch up with the American zeitgeist.â€œStar Wars: The Last Jediâ€ joins on June 26. The movie earned well over $1 billion at the box office and only debuted in theaters last December. Itâ€™s fairly rare that Netflix adds such a recently popular movie, so this is a particularly noteworthy addition.If youâ€™ve already seen the movie or simply arenâ€™t a fan of â€œStar Wars,â€ Netflix does have a few other movies joining this week.â€œMohawkâ€ is probably your best bet. With hope of escape diminishing, the captives try to fight back against their robot captor.Â Check out the trailer for â€œStar Wars: The Last Jediâ€ below (although youâ€™ve likely already seen it, as the YouTube version alone has over 50 million views).And if you want to stay informed about whatâ€™s joining Netflix on a weekly basis, make sure toÂ subscribe to the Streamline newsletter.Â This is part ofÂ Streamline, HuffPostâ€™s weekly recommendation service for streaming shows and movies. Every Saturday, Streamline ranks the best shows to watch online, including a focus onÂ Netflix.Â â€œStar Wars: The Last Jediâ€ | June 26Premise: A political faction called the Resistance is struggling to survive, while their enemy, the First Order, reigns supreme.With the Resistance on the brink of decimation, a long-shot effort is made to convince an old war hero to come join the fight.The lines of good and evil eventually become blurred in this battle and multiple characters question what theyâ€™re even fighting for.Is it actually good? Yes.There have been hilarious efforts to claim this movie is terrible. (An especially funny example is the â€œRemake The Last Jediâ€ campaign featured in the tweet below.)ButÂ â€œThe Last Jediâ€ is easily one of the best â€œStar Warsâ€ movies in the franchise. Itâ€™s the only one that truly rises to seek answers to the philosophical questions so many have looked to these movies for in the past. What is the nature of good and evil in war? How should religion inform a well-lived life? Is a world with extreme haves and have-nots morally corrupt?As with all of the â€œStar Warsâ€ movies, there are minor problems, of course. Characters act like idiotic children too often. Elements of the plot donâ€™t hold up with much scrutiny.Still, this is an extremely fun and thoughtful movie. So many scenes are beautifully shot. The action sequences are thrilling. Despite the long runtime, itâ€™s a movie well worth watching.Runtime: 2 hours, 32 minutesHereâ€™s the trailer ...June 26Â June 29Â Â June 30

Both Democrats and Republicans are pushing back against recent remarks made by Rep.Â Maxine WatersÂ (D-Calif.).At a Los Angeles rally on Saturday, Waters warned members of Trumpâ€™s Cabinet to be prepared for an onslaught of outrageÂ wherever they go should they continue to support the administrationâ€™s controversial zero toleranceÂ policy on undocumented immigrants.â€œYou think weâ€™re rallying now? You ainâ€™t seen nothing yet,â€ said Waters, whose remarks came one day after White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders was asked to leave a Virginia restaurant because of her role in the Trump administration. â€œAlready you have members of your Cabinet that are being booed out of restaurants ...Â protesters taking up at their house saying â€˜no peace, no sleep.â€™â€Waters took it a step further to encourage rally attendees to â€œmake sure we show up wherever we have to show up.â€â€œIf you see anybody from that Cabinet in a restaurant, in a department store, at a gasoline station, you get out and you create a crowd and you push back on them and you tell them theyâ€™re not welcome anymore, anywhere,â€ the congresswoman said.Over the weekend, Sanders tweeted about getting kicked out of The Red Hen in Lexington, Virginia, after the owner said she had concerns about serving someone affiliated with the administration. In recent weeks, senior adviser Stephen Miller and Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen NielsenÂ were also confronted while dining.The incident involving Sanders and Watersâ€™ response to it are now creating a larger conversation about civility and its place in politics.On Sunday, â€œThe Viewâ€ host Meghan McCain called Watersâ€™ impassioned speechÂ â€œextremely dangerous.â€â€œThis is absolutely insane,â€ McCain tweeted, later inciting the famous former FLOTUS Michelle Obama quote: â€œDonâ€™t ever again give me any of the â€˜when they go low, we go highâ€™ lip service.â€McCainâ€™s sentiments were echoed by many members of the GOP and several journalists onÂ a panel on CNNÂ Monday morning.RealClearPolitics editor A.B. Stoddard said Waters is â€œdoing everything she can to prevent her own promotionâ€ as chair of the Financial Services Committee.â€œThis is beyond overreach,â€ Stoddard said during the panel of her comments. â€œIt is so outrageous that she is trying to motivate voters on her side to be as divisive as President Trump. I just find it really unbelievable that this is the kind of thing theyâ€™re trying to stoke this mob mentality on the left. Itâ€™s the exact thing that will drive turnout on the other side.â€White House reporter Brian Karem, who has gone head-to-head with Sanders before,Â said he â€œwould have served her.â€â€œWhat happened to just a little bit of civility?â€ he asked.On Monday, House Minority Leader Rep.Â Nancy PelosiÂ (D-CA)Â added fuel to that fire and tweeted that while Watersâ€™ response to the incident might have been predictable, itâ€™s â€œunacceptable.â€Â President Donald Trump tweeted in response to Watersâ€™ remarks on Monday, calling the congresswoman an â€œextraordinarily low IQ person.â€ He also suggested Waters encouraged people to harm his supporters, when she did not.Sen. Chuck SchumerÂ (D-N.Y.) said Monday on the House floor that he â€œstronglyâ€ disagrees â€œwith those who advocate harassing folks who disagree with you.â€â€œNo one should call for the harassment of political opponents,â€ he said.When discussing the Red Hen incident on CBSâ€™ â€œFace the Nationâ€ Sunday, Rep. Elijah Cummings (D-Md.) said he thinks the Virginia restaurant owner should have served Sanders.Cummings did not mention Waters specifically but discussed his disapproval for the current incivility in politics.â€œThis tone is horrible. But again, I think President Trump has created this,â€ Cummings said. â€œSince he became president and even before, he has basically given people license to state things that are ugly.â€This article has been updated with comment from Schumer.Â

President Donald Trump announced on Friday that his Justice Department wouldÂ proceed with plansÂ to ban bump stocks, the firearms accessories the Las Vegas gunmanÂ used during his October attack on a country music festival that left 58 dead and hundreds more injured.Attorney General Jeff Sessions followed Trumpâ€™s announcement on FridayÂ with a statement saying heâ€™dÂ filed a proposed rules change that would â€œeffectivelyâ€ make the devices illegal under federal law.The moves mark Trumpâ€™s latest step toward unilaterally outlawing bump stocks and other similar accessories, which heâ€™s repeatedly vowed to do in the aftermath of the school shooting in Parkland, Florida, last month.The presidentâ€™s announcement came a day before the highly anticipated March for Our Lives, a well-attended series of ralliesÂ against gun violence on Saturday that was organized by student survivors of the Parkland shooting.Although Trump didnâ€™t personally address the movement from his golf resort in Mar-a-Lago, where he spent the weekend, his decision to roll out new action on bump stocks may have been an effort to send a message that he is doing something on guns â€• and in particular, a modest measure that receives broad bipartisan support.Â To get a better sense of the long and potentially difficult road ahead, letâ€™s take a closer look at whatâ€™s going on with this effort.First, itâ€™s important to understand that bump stocks are not firearms.Â A bump stock is a component, typically made of plastic, that replaces a rifleâ€™s standard stock and harnesses the gunâ€™s recoil to slide the firearm back and forth onto the shooterâ€™s trigger finger, allowing it to fire like an automatic weapon. (In the image below, the bump stock is the piece resting against the shooterâ€™s shoulder.)Federal law strictly regulates private ownership of automatic firearms, which the 1934 National Firearms Act defines asÂ â€œmachineguns.â€ But in most states, anyone who can buy a gun can get a semi-automatic rifle and a bump stock.Although firearms equipped with bump stocks may fire like so-called â€œmachineguns,â€ federal law specifically defines that term as any weapon that canÂ â€œshoot automatically more than one shot, without manual reloading, by a single function of the trigger.â€The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives has previously determined that it does not have the authority to regulate bump stocks because they donâ€™t fit this definition.Â Not only are bump stocks not firearms, but because the accessories still require users to pull the trigger each time they fire a cartridge, the agency has ruled that automatic firing is not technically activated by â€œsingle function of the trigger.â€The Trump administration now wants the ATF to change its determination. In his statement Friday, Sessions laid out a proposal to amend the regulations and clarify that bump stocks fall within the definition of â€œmachinegunâ€ under federal law,Â claiming that they do allow semi-automatic firearms to initiate a â€œcontinuous firing cycle with a single pull of the trigger.â€Because bump stocks â€[allow] the trigger to reset and continue firing without additional physical manipulation of the trigger by the shooter,â€ according to the document, â€œa semiautomatic firearm to which a bump-stock-type device is attached is able to produce automatic fire with a single pull of the trigger.â€Itâ€™s not yet clear if this attempt to change the reading of federal law will pass muster. Critics from across the politicalÂ spectrumÂ believe the administrationâ€™s move is likely to face a legal challenge and may ultimately be struck down.Others have argued that Congress should act instead, and change the federal statute on machine guns to specifically cover bump stocks and similar devices. Although congressional lawmakers have introduced bipartisan legislation to prohibit such accessories, the National Rifle Association and a number of Republicans have said theyâ€™d prefer that the ATF handle the matter by simply changing its ruling.GOP leaders on Capitol Hill have opted not to take up the bump stock issue,Â allowing them to duck accusations that theyâ€™re considering a gun ban.It remains to be seen how this will all play out, but if Trump is ultimately successful in his effort to ban bump stocks, it will take a while.Â Although Sessions filed hisÂ Notice of Proposed RulemakingÂ last week, it hadnâ€™t been published in the Federal Register as of Monday.Â Justice Department officials expect that to happen sometime this week,Â initiating a 90-day comment period for members of the public.At the end of that three-month window, the Justice Department must decide whether or not to proceed with a Final Rule. If it does, it must post that document in the Federal Register as well, in which it would lay out an effective date to be â€œnoâ€© lessâ€© thanâ€© thirtyâ€© daysâ€©â€ after publication.In the best-case scenario for the Trump administration, it would be at least four months before bump stocks are officially banned. At that point, anyone in possession of a bump stock or similar accessory would â€œbe required to surrender, destroy, or otherwise render the devices permanently inoperable,â€Â or be subject to stiff penalties under federal law, including imprisonment of up to 10 years or a fine of up to $250,000.

The fine folks of Pawnee, Indiana, said â€œKnopeâ€ to gun violence over the weekend.Actress Natalie Morales, who played Lucy on â€œParks and Recreation,â€ posted a photo to Instagram on Saturday that features herself and other notable cast members and guest stars from the NBC sitcom attending the March For Our Lives protest in Washington, D.C.Standing around Morales in the picture are, from left,Â Aubrey Plaza (who played April Ludgate), Paul Rudd (Bobby Newport),Â Adam Scott (Ben Wyatt) and Billy Eichner (Craig Middlebrooks).Scott,Â Plaza andÂ Eichner also posted the picture.Plaza and Morales boasted signs that promoted the Everytown for Gun SafetyÂ movement, while Eichner toted a sign that read â€œChange gun laws or change Congress.â€ Rudd wore a T-shirt that said â€œProtect kids, not guns.â€Although â€œParks and Recâ€ star Amy Poehler (Leslie Knope) isnâ€™t featured in the photo, she did show her support for the protest with a photo of herself wearing a March For Our Lives T-shirt on theÂ Amy Poehlerâ€™s Smart GirlsÂ Instagram account.â€œâ€˜We stand with you, young people. I applaud your bravery and your incredible poise, and the fire that you have started will not go out. It will only get stronger, and we will help fan the flames.â€™ - Amy Poehler,â€ the caption reads.Many â€œParks and Recâ€ actors, including Nick Offerman (Ron Swanson) and Ben Schwartz (Jean-Ralphio) who are not pictured at the rally, have been showing support for the Parkland survivorsâ€™ movement since the studentsÂ announced the rallyÂ for gun policy reform in February.Check out some of their posts below:

Dozens of Wisconsin high school students are spending their spring breaks this week walking more than 50 miles to House Speaker Paul Ryanâ€™s (R-Wis.) hometown of Janesville to deliver a message: Pass meaningful gun reform legislation now.A group of students from Shorewood High School, roughly four miles north of Milwaukee,Â organized the march to call out Ryan for blocking gun legislation reform and to demand lawmakers take immediate action to curb gun violence.â€œWe started 50 Miles More to keep the national demand for gun reform going after the March 24th March for Our Lives events are over,â€Â according to theÂ movementâ€™s website. â€œOur generation has grown up watching school shootings destroy lives and then get swept out of the spotlight. We refuse to let this happen again.â€Itâ€™s no coincidence that the four-day, 54-mile trek from Madison began Sunday â€• exactly 53 years after Martin Luther King Jr. led thousands of civil rights activists into Montgomery, Alabama, to conclude a five-day, 54-mile march that began in Selma.â€œWe looked to history and an earlier generation of young leaders who fueled real change,â€ theÂ 50 Miles More websiteÂ says. â€œIn 1965, civil rights leaders organized the multi-day, 54-mile Selma to Montgomery marches. Those 54 long miles took us a long way toward progress, and are the inspiration for our march.â€March participation swelled to at least 40 young people by Monday, with students across Wisconsin joining the journey.Â At the end of every mile walked, the 50 More Miles participants honor a victim of gun violence. The march is expected to end Wednesday with a rally in Janesville.â€œWeâ€™re definitely a little sore in the feet and in some of the joints, but our spirits are high,â€Â Brendan Fardella,Â a 17-year-old student at Shorewood High School, told HuffPost by phone Monday as he marched through the â€œmiddle of nowhere.â€â€œThis is definitely what Iâ€™d like to be doing on my spring break,â€Â he said. â€œIt wasnâ€™t my original plan, but Iâ€™m much happier doing this and effecting some change with my fellow students than just being on a beach somewhere.â€The marchers have been subjected to a few negative statements from passing drivers and bikers but overall have felt supported,Â said Alemitu Caldart,Â who also attends Shorewood High School.â€œWe just respond by saying, â€˜Spread love, not hate,â€™â€Â Alemitu, 15, told HuffPost.â€œ[We hope] to show people that weâ€™re not done until actual change is made,â€ added Alemitu, who plans to participate in a spoken-word performance about gun violence at the rally in Janesville. â€œWeâ€™re still here. Weâ€™re stubborn. Weâ€™re going to keep on fighting for our lives to be safe every single day.â€Asked by HuffPost for comment on the march, a spokeswoman for Ryan said heÂ â€œrespects those expressing their views.â€Â â€œThe House recently enacted new laws to keep children safe without infringing on constitutional rights,â€ she added.But the legislation she likely referred to, which includes expanding federal background checks for gun purchases, is only a tiny step forward when it comes to the reform proposals pushed by many firearm safety advocates.Â The 50 Miles More movement laid out a heftier list of demands on their website:Military-style weapons, and all weapons of war, should be banned from civilian society.All accessories that turn semi-automatic weapons into automatic weapons, such as bump stocks, should be banned.Four-day waiting period on all gun purchases.Require background checks on all gun sales.Raise the legal purchasing age of all guns to 21â€œI stand here today to say to all of you that now is the time to do the impossible,â€Â Katie Eder, an 18-year-old organizer of the march, said Saturday in a speech at Milwaukeeâ€™s March for Our Lives.Â â€œIf the politicians wonâ€™t listen to us, if the politicians wonâ€™t make the change, then come November, we are prepared to change the politicians.â€This article has been updated with quotes from students participating in the march.Â
